text: CLOSE on a Polaroid of a dimly lit COUPLE locked in a sex embrace. We cannot see their faces.
(tortured) God grant me the Serenity to accept the things I cannot change... Our view travels sensuously down the Woman's naked torso find the Man's head buried between her legs.
Why do you fight it so hard, Earl?
Courage to change the things I can...
Come on, you've been a good boy for a long time, you deserve a little fun. Our view moves back up to the Woman's breasts.
EARL BROOKS' reflection in a mirror. Earl, in his 40's, h on a tuxedo. He's in front of a sink in a Public Bathroom he's whispering to his image.
... and Wisdom to know the difference. Picking up speed against the hunger in his head:
Living one day at a time, Enjoying one moment at a time, Accepting hardship as a pathway to peace... From far away comes the sound of applause.
MEN in tuxedos and WOMEN in gowns. Mr. Brooks is seated at one of the front tables with his wife, EMMA, also 40's.
The audience's hands are coming together for what a MAN a the microphone has just said. Mr. Brooks is smiling but not clapping; and although his don't move we can hear:

(even faster now) ... Taking, as He did, this sinful world as it is, not as I would have it. Trusting that He will make all things right if I surrender to His will. That I may be reasonably happy in this life, And supremely happy with Him forever in the next. Amen. The Man at the microphone raises his arms to quiet the Audience.
I could go on and on about what a great guy Earl is, how he cuts his toe nails... Everyone laughs.

... how he gives freely of his time and money, but let's get Earl up here to speak for himself. Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you a businessman, a philanthropist, a great friend and the Evanston Chamber of Commerce Man of the Year... Mr. Earl Brooks. Mr. Brooks kisses Emma, stands and after accepting congratulations along the way, arrives at the podium.
Thank you all very much. The first thing I would like to say is... I don't even know how I cut my toe nails. Applause and laughter from the Audience.
Twenty years ago when I started the Brooks Box Factory I never dreamed I would one day be standing here.
A silver Lexus LS 430 glides past us.
Did you see Sis Wallace's dress?
Mr. Brooks is driving. Emma is in the passenger seat. The holding hands.
You could see her nipples. At her age she should keep those things hidden. Mr. Brooks is only listening to his Wife with one ear and underneath what she is saying we can barely hear:
God grant me the Serenity to accept...
The only thing that would have made this evening more perfect is if Jane had been here.
She called. She has mid terms coming up.
She's dropping out, you know.
We'll see.
Nothing she does is wrong to you, is it?... Mr. Brooks doesn't rise to the bait.
Well she missed a good party... As she continues, we look at Mr. Brooks and Emma's voice fades to a murmur.
In the back seat, a Man leans out from behind Mr. Brooks' head. This is MARSHALL. He's 50 plus. Emma can neither see nor hear him. Marshall exists only i Mr. Brooks's mind.
Come on, Earl, give yourself a break, you know you want to do this.
No.
You're the fucking 'man of the year', you deserve it. It's not like it's not set up. You already know how to by-pass the alarm, you know how to pick the locks. Tonight's the perfect night.
(over his shoulder) No, Marshall, I said 'no'!
I heard you, Earl, but you don't mean 'no'. Emma feels Mr. Brooks's distance.
What's the matter? Mr. Brooks pulls himself back into the moment.
Nothing.
You were frowning.
I was thinking of what I didn't say in the speech.
They laughed, they were touched, I don't think anyone felt left out.
(from the back seat) They have their dance class tonight. What if we go by and just look at them. There's no harm in just having a look.
No means 'no', Marshall.
Please... pretty please.
(to Emma) The food tonight was very good, but I wasn't crazy about the dessert. Would you like to stop somewhere and get something sweet?

head_text.subj: INT. ICE CREAM PARLOR N NIGHT

text: In a booth, Mr. Brooks and Emma are sharing a Sundae. Mr. Brooks steals a look at the Arthur Murray dance class tha taking place behind the full-length windows fronting the second floor of the Building across the street.
... Labradors are supposed to be nice, or maybe a rescue mutt...
The Pound's a pretty sad place; if you want me to, I'll go with you.

There's an Irish Lab I read about, and I think the breeder is... Mr. Brooks turns his attention back to the Dancers and ag Emma's voice fades to a murmur. Both Mr. Brooks and Marshall who is seated on the other s of Emma are focused on one particular COUPLE. The Man and Woman are not great dancers nor are they especially attractive, but Mr. Brooks and Marshall are fascinated with them. Marshall leans forward and looking slyly around Emma at M Brooks:
I bet your dick's getting hard, isn't it, just imagining what they would look like dead? Savoring the ice-cream, Mr. Brooks nods.
Two story modern. Not ostentatious, but the elegance of t line and the grounds say there's big money here.

Through the door of the DRESSING AREA, Emma can be seen taking off her evening clothes. Hidden by the darkness on the other side of the bed, Mr. Brooks is hunched forward on a chair, his head in his han His bow tie is undone, but he's still wearing his Tuxedo. obvious torment, he is whispering to himself.

... I can't do this, I can't do this, I can't do this, please don't let me do this, God grant me the Serenity to accept the things I cannot change... In the DRESSING AREA Emma is putting on her sleep-wear. Mr. Brooks steps into doorway.
I'm going to stay up a while, maybe go to the studio and play with some glazes.
Okay, I'm going to read. If I'm not awake, wake me when you come back. Mr. Brooks comes forward, puts his arms around Emma and h her, then easing back, kisses her.
I thought you were wonderful tonight.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE BROOKS HOUSE N NIGHT

text: Mr. Brooks exits the back door and starts down a path tha leads away from the house.

(to himself) Don't do this, don't do this, please don't do this, don't do this, don't do, please don't do this... He passes through a screen of trees and arrives at a smal beautiful industrial-looking Building. No windows except for a narrow strip on three sides just under the edge of the roof. Mr. Brooks lets himself in with a key.

Exquisitely unique handmade handglazed bowls, vases, cups plates are scattered haphazardly on shelves and tables ar the room. This is Mr. Brooks's CERAMICS STUDIO. Mr. Brooks turns on the big industrial kiln and sets the temperature, then in a series of quick cuts changes out o his tuxedo into his work clothes which he selects from a dozen identical pairs of khaki shirts and pants hanging i closet. Below the pants and shirts are a dozen pairs of identical leather work shoes. The windbreaker he puts on is also fr dozen identical windbreakers. He takes a set of car keys off a hook next to a door whic opens into a garage. Under the light is an older model no descript Toyota.
The Toyota backs into an alley and with the garage door closing behind it, pulls away.
Marshall is up front with Mr. Brooks.
Oh Lordy, Earl my boy, I've missed this! We are going to have so much fun!
This is the last time, Marshall. Understand me?! The very last time!

A mixture of modest houses and apartment buildings. Mr. Brooks's Toyota is parked in the semi-dark cast by a tree We rise over the car, over the trees, over the houses to other side of the block and come down to find Mr. Brooks working the lock on the side door of a small BUNGALOW. He has on surgical gloves. The pick is extracted, the handle turned. The door opens. There's a chain. Mr. Brooks removes a pair of bent rubber tipped forceps f a pocket, inserts it in the chain, pulls the door to, giv the tool a twist and gently pushes the door inward. The chain has been released.

Mr. Brooks quietly closes the door and holding his breath stands very still and listens. There's a faint indistinct sound coming from the recesses the house. Mr. Brooks's feet glide out of the PANTRY. Now coming slightly behind him is another pair of legs encased in da slacks. Move up; the person in the black slacks is Marshall. In the middle of the KITCHEN, the sound is now recognizab It's the moans of a Couple fucking. This disturbs Mr. Bro he hesitates. Marshall leans in and hisses fiercely in his ear.

Don't you dare quit on me, you piece of shit. I want to see what they're doing. Mr. Brooks's spine stiffens and he's going forward again. Entering a HALLWAY, he reaches into his jacket. When his reappears it's inside a Ziplock bag, his fingers around t butt of a silenced pistol. He brings the hand and bag to his mouth and tightens the Ziplock against his wrist. The two Men arrive at a door that's slightly ajar. Behind the sounds of the love-making are becoming more intense. Mr. Brooks nudges the door with his foot. It opens enough he and Marshall to see the Couple inside. The Man and Woman from the Arthur Murray dance class are naked on the bed. As much as Mr. Brooks hates himself for it he loves watch He can now hear his heart beating in his ears. He begins to breathe in unison with the Couple, but his expression is distant almost clinical. When the Couple climaxes, when they come, Mr. Brooks's fa goes blank. On the bed the Woman rolls off her Partner and the two of them lie there basking in the afterglow. Behind them Mr. Brooks pushes the door fully open and sli into the ROOM. They don't know he's there until he speaks
Hello. Both the Man and Woman jump with surprise and look. The W screams and scrabbles at the sheet to cover herself.
What the fuck?! Then he sees the gun.
Hey, man, don't...

(to the Woman) Be quiet and sit up. In an attempt to get away, the Woman pushes herself back against the wall. She can't take her eyes off Mr. Brooks she can't stop screaming. POP! A hole appears above her left eye. The impact of Mr. Brooks's High Velocity .22 slug bounces her head off the wall. The screaming stops. The Man opens his mouth and begins to shake. POP! The bul through his brain makes him instantly dead and he crumple onto the Girl. Mr. Brooks looks at what he's done. His nostrils flare at scent of death. Then he moves, he's got work to do. On hi way to the bed, the pistol goes into his pocket.

(barks) Whoa, Earl, what the fuck is this?!! Mr. Brooks snaps a look. The curtains of the bedroom window are open; and over hal the Apartments in a four story Building on the other side an alley can see into this room. Most of their windows are dark. And there's no one lookin out of the windows that are lit.
These pigs liked to fuck with the blinds open, you should have known that, Earl. This is a big mistake for you, Earl.
(going to the window) Almost like I want to get caught, huh, Marshall?
Well, don't fucking do that. I don't think either of us would enjoy spending the rest of our lives in jail or a lethal injection.
Yes, sir. He grabs a side of cloth in either hand and yanks the curtains closed.
CLOSE on a Polaroid of the dance Couple in a sexual pose. attitude of the bodies is awkward and very reminiscent of ones in the Polaroid we opened the movie with.
Mr. Brooks is kneeling naked in front of the kiln where h murder clothes are being reduced to ash. Arranged on the floor are Polaroids of the dance Couple i sexual positions.

Please forgive me... Please forgive me... As we look closer at the Photographs we realize by a smea blood here and there and the distortion of the limbs that these tableaus were arranged after the Couple was killed. One by one, Mr. Brooks picks up his souvenirs. He lingers over the last image; and from where he's sitting on the e of a table:
Don't even think about it. You know the rules. Reluctantly Mr. Brooks throws the Polaroids into the fire the kiln.
Now go up and make love to your beautiful wife. He leaves. In the kiln, the Polaroids burst into flame.
The sunlight exposes its charm. If it weren't for the Police tape, the UNIFORMED OFFICERS and the PLAINCLOTHES DETECTIVES, it looks like it would b cool place to live.
An OLDER DETECTIVE, an African-American, comes out on the porch and calls to two other DETECTIVES who are drinking coffee on the lawn:
Where the fuck is Atwood?!
I called ten minutes ago, they said she was on her way.
She doesn't get here soon, these bodies won't even be dead anymore? A Uniformed Cop standing guard at the tape:
You looking for the lady Cop?
Yeah.
She's here. She's been sitting in her car right over there for the last half hour.
Oh, Christ.

Special Detective TRACY ATWOOD, somewhere in her 30's, is behind the wheel. The door is open. By the expression on her face we might guess that Detecti Atwood has simply forgotten to get out of the car. On the seat next to her is a copy of the Chicago Tribune. headline of a middle article on the first page reads: THE HANGMAN ESCAPES. Move up to Atwood's face. The Older Detective followed by Younger Detective approaches.
You thinking of joining us anytime soon, Atwood? Atwood doesn't look at the Detectives for a long beat and when she does her expression is not friendly.
I really hated yesterday, Snyder, and then today came along. As she gets out of the car, the Men notice the bandages o her wrists and falling into step with her on the way to t house.
What happened to your wrists? Atwood holds up her hands to reveal the extent of the bandages.
I tried to commit suicide. The Young Detective laughs. Atwood whirls on him.
What's so funny?
Eh... I... I don't know, I heard it was because you were drunk and got into a fight with a fish tank. Atwood sticks her finger into the Young Detective's chest
Who are you gonna believe? Me or the fucking fish?!
Eh... you.
Good. Atwood turns and leaves the Men.
(under his breath) She's nuts!
And rich. They catch up to Atwood who has squatted down to examine lock on the front door.
There are some scratches in the side door cylinder. Other than that no signs of forced entry. The alarm was armed and we even had to cut the security chains to get in.
(straightens up) This guy hasn't been active for over two years... She enters the house.
From the way Atwood looks at her surroundings as she cros the Living Room we get the feel that this Woman misses nothing.
... we think he's either dead or in jail on some other charge. This is probably a copycat. Detective Snyder points her down the Hall toward the Bedr and follows.
That's why we called you. You're the God that tells us peons if we have a simple murder here or something we can dump on you.

Bite yourself. Atwood arrives in the doorway of the BEDROOM where the murders took place and stops. The Bodies of the dance Couple are now on the floor. The is propped up against the bed in a sitting position. The Woman has her head in the Man's crotch. Almost like Mr. Brooks, Atwood's nostrils flare, but in Atwood's case it's not the scent of death that arouses he but it's like she's searching for the scent of her prey. In a glance she memorizes the Room, then steps inside.
The Crime Scene TECHNICIANS shift to accommodate Atwood's inspection.

(indicating the Victims) He always rearranges the bodies, but this is out of character. He has never left them in such a crude position. Usually it's more romantic with their arms around each other, kissing, their mouths open, their tongues touching.
So we have a copycat?
Where are the thumbprints? Snyder points to a bare space of wall above the bed. Atwo leans in to look at two bloody 'thumbprints' placed side side.
One his one hers?
That's what it looks like.
What's that? There are two holes gouged into the plaster of the wall.

The bullets went completely through the victims. The killer recovered the slugs. Atwood unfolds and after another look around the room goe the window and cracks the curtains. There's the four story Apartment Building across the alle its windows staring down at her.
Were these open or closed when you got here?
Closed. Atwood tries the cord, the curtains are stuck.
Hmm... She returns her attention to the murder scene.
It has never been revealed to the public that the Thumbprint Killer retrieves the slugs.
So this one's yours.
I don't fucking need this. She doubles back and cracks the curtains for another look the four story Apartment Building.
Have you checked the tenants of that building?
Only a few of them are home, they say they didn't see anything. We checked the whole neighborhood, so far nobody saw a thing. Atwood nods and turns back to the bodies.
Leaving them like this, he must have been angry at them for some reason. She reaches down and runs a hand over the carpet.
Where would they keep their vacuum cleaner. A puzzled Snyder follows her out of the room.
Atwood opens a service closet. There's the Vacuum Cleaner
I'll bet you a hundred bucks, Snyder, there is no bag in that vacuum cleaner.
I have no idea what you're looking for. Atwood unzips the cover. There is no bag inside.
He vacuumed the house and took the bag.
Oh, shit. That is scary smart.
Detective Atwood is standing on an empty capped plastic gallon milk carton looking over the fence into the back y of the Murder House. Snyder has his hand on her back to steady her.
Okay. He releases her. She hops down and directs her attention the four story Apartment Building.
Our best hope is if someone in there saw something. A MAN comes out from behind the next door fence and strid purposefully toward them.
Detective Tracy Atwood?
Yes.
This is for you. She accepts the official looking document being offered.
You have been served.
You fucking asshole!! I'm in the middle of a fucking murder investigation!!
(backing away) Hey, take it easy lady, I'm just the messenger.
Goddamit!!
What is it?
My soon to be ex-husband's scumbag lawyer is trying to show me how painful she can make my life if I don't give them what they want.
This is not the Doctor.
The doctor was a couple years ago. This one is my stupid mistake.
An AA Meeting is getting started. Mr. Brooks is one of th ASSEMBLED. The LEADER steps into the semicircle of Men an Women.
Are there any new members? A WOMAN comes forward.
Hi, my name is Vaughn and I'm an alcoholic. She rejoins the circle. Mr. Brooks separates himself from Others.
Hi, my name is Earl and I'm an addict. When he rejoins the circle, Marshall is there to greet hi
You're such a fucking hypocrite. If you were honest you would step out there and say 'Hi, I'm Earl. I killed two people last night and I really got off on it, but I need your help to be cured.'

I'm different Marshall, I won't argue that with you. This is the only place that has ever helped me be normal and I've been straight up until last night for the past two years. I'm not going to kill again and I'm not going to quit coming here because it upsets you.
Yeah but for the next 29 days you're going to have to step out there and say 'Hi, I'm Earl, I'm an addict.' And everybody will know you fell off the wagon. Don't you feel stupid doing that?
No. I feel good.

head_text.subj: EXT. INDUSTRIAL SECTION OF CHICAGO N DAY

text: A Cab arrives at the Front Entrance of the BROOKS BOX FACTORY, a long three story brick Building. A YOUNG WOMAN, 19, is dropped off along with an assortmen luggage and boxes.

head_text.subj: INT. BROOKS BOX FACTORY N DAY

text: It's loud. We follow a thin piece of cardboard as one mac deals it off the bottom of a stack into the maw of anothe machine. That machine prints one side of the cardboard blue. It is handed off to the third machine which cuts the flap The fourth machine folds and glues those flaps and spits piece of cardboard out onto a conveyor belt as a box. Wearing safety glasses and ear protectors along with his business suit, Mr. Brooks picks up the box and hands it t one of three similarly attired MEN, standing nearby.
This is not the top of the line or the bottom, but for the money we're talking about this is the quality I can provide you. As Mr. Brooks talks the Men pass the box between them.
Your packaging is the first impression your customers will have of your product...
Mr. Brooks, your daughter is waiting for you in your office. A surprised Mr. Brooks grabs a quick look at the PA Speak then continues.
... We'd love to work you with on the design. It's fun to challenge our machines. If you check around, you'll find we're not the cheapest, but we are the best.
On his way through to his office, Mr. Brooks smiles absen at a MAN waiting on the couch. The pleasant-looking Man i his early 30's, nods. Mr. Brooks stops at his SECRETARY's desk.
Sunday, did Jane call and say she was coming?
I would have given you that message, Mr. Brooks. She has boxes and suitcases downstairs.
Hold my calls.

head_text.subj: INT. MR. BROOKS' OFFICE N DAY

text: (coming in) What are you doing here, Gorgeous?
The 19 year old Girl we saw arrive by cab stands up and throws her arms around Mr. Brooks.
I'm sorry, Daddy, please don't be angry with me. Mr. Brooks kisses Jane on the forehead and goes to sit at desk.
I can guess what you've done, but why don't you tell me and then I'll decide.
I dropped out of school.
Okay. Have you told your mother this?
No. I wanted to speak to you first.
You'll have to tell her, I'm not going to do that for you, and then together the three of us will decide where to go from here.
I've thought a lot about this, Dad. College is a waste of time for me.
I don't know how you know that half way through your Freshman year, but...
You didn't go to college, Dad, and you're successful. I want to come and work for you. Sitting on the couch:
She's not telling you everything, she's hiding something.
I know. (to Jane) I'm not hiring right now.

Just listen to me. What would happen to the business if, God forbid, something happened to you? Mom would probably have to sell to strangers. I'm willing to start at the bottom, you can treat me as a regular employee, I want to learn everything there is to know about running the box business, and then when the time comes, the business would stay in the family.
That's sweet, but you're talking about emotion, not business. In fact your mother and I came very close to selling out last year.
What?!
If we had been offered a little more money, and they may come back to us, we will sell.
What would you do without...?! There's a knock on the door.
Yes? Sunday, the secretary, comes in and crossing to Mr. Brook
I'm sorry, I know you didn't want to be disturbed, the Man in the waiting room insisted I give you this. She hands Mr. Brooks a letter-size envelope.
He said you would find what's inside very interesting.
What is he? A salesman?
He won't say. I've never seen him before. I can tell him to go away if you want me to.
That's okay. She leaves. Slicing the flap of the envelope, Mr. Brooks picks up with Jane.

Part of spending the four years in college is to... Mr. Brooks can now see the contents of the envelope. Two snapshot-size PHOTOS taken with a high speed digital camera. One shows the right side of Mr. Brooks's cheek. He is in no way identifiable, but that blur of flesh appe to be looking at the dead dance Couple. The second Photo is a clear shot of Mr. Brooks closing th curtains with the dead dance Couple behind him. Neither Mr. Brooks's voice or his face betray the enormit what he's looking at.
... eh... to give yourself the chance to find out who you are and what you want to do.
I'll talk to Mom, but I'm not going back to school.
Where would you live?
To save money I would move back home, but no rules, no curfew, I want to be treated like an adult.
Mr. Brooks allows himself a slight smile.
Would you pay for your food, would you pay rent?
No, dad, you're a very wealthy man, you can afford to keep me. Mr. Brooks presses his Intercom.
Sunday, would you show the gentleman who gave you the envelope to the conference room, and tell him I'll meet him there and... (to Jane) What happened to the BMW?
A friend is driving it across country, it'll be here next weekend.
(to Sunday, through Intercom) And get Jane a cab. He picks up the phone and holds it out to Jane.
Call your mother.
Are you going to give me a job?
If it were up to me, and I think your mother will agree with this, you should go back to school.
Mr. Brooks comes around the corner. He's raving at Marsha who's walking beside him.
You see all of this?! The factory, the houses, the cars, the money, the respect!!...
A different angle in the same hallway shows Mr. Brooks walking away from us. A passing EMPLOYEE crosses him. The nod to each other. Marshall is nowhere in sight.
... I like them! I don't want to lose them! And then we're back to the original angle and Marshall is again in the picture.
... That's why I didn't want to do the dance Couple!

Stop your fucking whining, Earl, you enjoyed doing that Couple just as much as I did, and look on the bright side, he came to us he didn't go to the Cops. If he tries to shake us down we kill him. Period. We make it fun but we kill him. End of story.
The Man from the Reception Area is nervously admiring a display of Mr. Brooks's ceramic pieces. He turns at the s of the door opening behind.
What can I do for you, Mr...?
... Let's say, 'Smith'.
Okay, Mr. Smith. Mr. Brooks motions him to a seat.
(sitting) Before you get the wrong impression, Mr. Brooks, I'm not here to shake you down.
(holding up the photos) Then these are the only copies of these photos and you have no others.
No. I have other copies and other photos, and if something were to happen to me...
How did you find me, Mr. Smith?
You're 'Man of the Year', Mr. Brooks. Your picture was in the paper. If it hadn't been, I don't know what I would have done.
Lucky me. What is it that I can help you with?

I've been watching that Couple for months, they liked to make love with the blinds open. Sometimes I would take pictures, you know, visual aides for later. It was fun, it was a great way to get off; I thought, until I saw you kill them. I have to tell you I have never ever felt a rush like that ever. I know you're the Thumbprint killer, you've done this before. What I want is to go with you the next time you kill someone. And I would like that to be soon. From the end of the table, Marshall cackles a laugh.
And you were worried that this was going to be unpleasant. The answer is simple. Just tell him you've decided never to kill again and he'll go away.
You enjoy watching me suffer, don't you?
In a word, yes.
Where do you think he has the other pictures?

He put them in a safety deposit box but I'll bet the box is at the bank where he has his checking account and the key is on his keychain. He really wants to do this, he's not going to go to the cops. Mr. Smith who has grown uneasy under Mr. Brooks's stare swallows:
So do we have a deal?
From the angle of these pictures... (taps the envelope) ... you live on the third floor of the apartment building across the alley from the Couple's house.
Well... eh.
Yes or no, Mr. Smith? Mr. Smith nods 'yes'.
What time do you get home from work?
Six thirty, seven, depending on the traffic.
You can never come here again, you can never call me. Do you understand that?
Yes.
Tomorrow night, not tonight, tomorrow night, at eight o'clock, leave your apartment and walk east. I'll pick you up.
If you're thinking of doing anything to me, Mr. Brooks...
We're both aware of the rules, Mr. Smith, but I feel I must warn you. If it turns out that you enjoy killing, it can become very addictive. It could ruin your life.
I want to do this.
(looks at Marshall) Have I covered everything?
I can't think of anything else. Mr. Brooks stands up and opens the door.
I'll see you tomorrow night, Mr. Smith. On his way out, Mr. Smith nods. Mr. Brooks closes the doo His chin drops on his chest and he sighs.
(under his breath) Please God, please help me find a way not to do this.
Detective Atwood comes out of the CROWD on the sidewalk a enters a Highrise.
Atwood and her ATTORNEYS, a gray-haired Man in his 60's, an Asian Woman about the same age as Atwood are on one si of the table.
JESSE, Atwood's soon to be ex-husband, very handsome, slightly younger than Atwood, and SHEILA, his attractive divorce lawyer, sit across from them.

We've talked to our client and we've come up with a number that we feel is more than fair. Atwood is not happy with this. The Attorney slides a shee paper to Sheila. She turns it over. On it is written: $750,000 -.
We can have a check for that amount in your office by 6 o'clock.
We told you at the beginning what we want and that hasn't changed.
You know as well as I do, Counselor, if we go to court you're not going to get a million five.
I don't know. Let's see. She holds up the front page of the Chicago Tribune. "THE HANGMAN ESCAPES" story is circled in red.

This is the front page of yesterday's paper... (reads) 'Hangman Escapes'... eh... now, here it is... 'after torturing the young women, Thorton Meeks would hang them in public places - church steeples, balconies, Freeway overpasses'... Your client captured Mr. Meeks. This is just one example of the cases my client lived through when he was married to your client.
Your client knew Detective Atwood was a homicide detective when he married her.
But he had no idea of the mental anguish that being in close proximity to her work would cause him.
What about the mental anguish I went through being in close proximity to him. Who's gonna pay me for that?
We don't need to get into this, Tracy.
Yes, we do. I was the one who paid for everything while we were married, and now I'm being asked to give him a bonus for spending time with me when I've already paid for it in the first place.
(to Atwood) Tracy, this is not a lot of money for you, and you know how upset I was when Meeks said that he was going to escape and he would come back and kill you.
We're quite willing to find out what a court would think that mental anguish is worth.
Jesse... Darling?... you know the best thing that could happen to me right now? That you get hit by a truck and die.
(smiles) That's it! Mr. Vialo and I are leaving. (she and Jesse stand up) You've threatened my client, we're going to ask for a restraining order, and we'll see you in court.
The door closes behind them.
That's going to cost you, Tracy.
(standing up) Fuck it. It felt good.

Moonlight seeps around the blinds to reveal Mr. Smith asl in bed. Beyond the open BEDROOM door down the hall is only darkne until the eruption of illumination from a penlight momentarily outlines the figure of a Man. Then we're looking at what the penlight sees. A keyring. Hands in surgical gloves isolate the - safety deposit key - and press it into a soft wax block where it leaves its impression. The light goes off. In the BEDROOM at the end of the hallway, Mr. Smith begin snore. The Figure coasts silently toward the sound. Mr. Smith's face is sideways on the pillow. The snores an little drool burbles out of the corner of his mouth. WHOOMP!! The impact of something landing on the bed bounc Mr. Smith upright and awake.
Ahhh!!! Ahhh!!! Ahhh!!! The beam from the penlight hits him in the face. He raise his hands to shield his eyes.

Don't worry, if I were here to kill you, you would already be dead. The penlight leaves Mr. Smith and Mr. Brooks places it deliberately under his own chin casting long sinister sha up his face. He's sitting on the bed next to Mr. Smith.
After you left today, I realized our friendship was a little one- sided.

So when we meet tomorrow night would you be so kind as to bring all of the pictures and the memory card from your camera. That way we can like each other simply for who we are. If you don't show up, I will presume you've gone to the police and I will kill you. Even if I go to jail because of you, someone will find you wherever you are and kill you. The penlight goes off. There's total silence.
(squeaks) Mr. Brooks?... He squints into the black.

Mr. Brooks?... Finally he gathers the courage to extend a shaky hand. Th bedside lamp goes on. The room is empty. Cautiously Mr. S swings his legs out of bed and stands up. He forces himself to go to the door and from there curls arm around the jamb into the darkness. The HALL light is dazzling. A peek into the BATHROOM shows there is nobody there. He continues on into the LIVING ROOM. His camera equipment is on the table. The tripod is still up. There is no sign of Mr. Brooks. Mr. Smith eyes the front door. It's closed and the 'secur chain' is in place!! Another quick scan of the room. It sure seems that he's alone. He opens the front door the length of the chain and looks and down the hallway. It's empty. Slowly he closes the do Standing in the light of his LIVING ROOM, Mr. Smith is mo scared and strangely more excited than he's ever been in life.
Wow!...

In a robe and pajamas, Mr. Brooks comes down the HALLWAY carrying a glass of milk. The door to his Daughter's ROOM partly open. By the nightlight in the plug at the head of bed he can see she's asleep.
Mr. Brooks walks to the bed, leans over and kisses his Daughter on the cheek.
(quietly) It's nice to have you home. He leaves.
The early rays of the sun are moving down the tall buildi
A garbage truck is picking up the trash.

Dressed for work and a smile on his face, Mr. Brooks come down the stairs. In the BREAKFAST ROOM, the mood is decidedly different. H Wife and Daughter are leaning against opposite walls star at the floor.
What's wrong?
Ask your daughter what the real reason is she dropped out of school.
I keep telling you it's not the reason.

You wanted to go to college, you had good grades in High School, your father helped you get into Stanford, we're paying a ton of money, if this is not the reason, then please dear God tell me the reason.
(picking up an orange juice)
Why does your mother think you dropped out of school?
I'm pregnant. (to her Mother) And it's not the reason I dropped out. Being pregnant wouldn't stop me from going to school if I wanted to go.
Who's the father?
Some guy I was seeing.
Does he know?
Yes, he's a married man and he doesn't want to have anything to do with me.
Oh, Honey, I'm so sorry.
I'm going to have an abortion anyway, so there is nothing to get upset about. I wasn't even going to tell you guys. Mr. Brooks looks directly at his Daughter.
There will be no abortion.
JANE
Daddy, you are not going to tell me what to do. It's my body and I will do what I want to do with it. Mr. Brooks's eyes find Emma's. Almost imperceptibly she shakes her head 'no'. MR. BROOKS
(to his Daughter) You're right. I'm sorry. I said it wrong. I'm not trying to tell you what to do. I'm trying to say that a grandchild would be a wonderful gift for your mother and me. EMMA
Please, Honey, don't have an abortion. JANE
Would you really want to have a grandchild, even though I'm not married? MR. BROOKS
Yes. The child is what's important. We would love it and cherish it completely and help you raise it. JANE
If it means that much to you, I'll think about it.
Walking to the Lexus, Mr. Brooks notices Marshall waiting him on the passenger side. MR. BROOKS
(smiles) Well, we were right, she was hiding something. MARSHALL
(flat) Pregnant's not all of it. She's hiding something bigger. Much bigger. MR. BROOKS
You think so?
I know so, and so do you.

Large and small Color Photographs pinned to a corkboard create a Collage of the dance Couple murder scene. Standing in front of this is CAPTAIN LISTER, a tall slim faced Woman in her mid-fifties, and the lead Crime Scene Technician we saw earlier at the Murder House.
It's not what's here, it's what's not here that's interesting. There's not a trace of anything foreign. If I didn't know better I'd say these people were killed by a ghost.
The autopsy found a tiny piece of plastic in the female victim's brain.
We're checking with the ammunition manufacturers.
(entering the room) That's a dead end, he bags the gun.
I don't understand.

He ziplocks a one gallon plastic freezer bag to his wrist over the gun. Bang. Bang. A little bit of plastic is carried by the first slug, the ejected shells go into the bag and it limits the powder residue. (to Captain Lister) I hear you were looking for me.
(to the Technician) Sigy...
Yeah, okay... (to Atwood) Did you find anything? Did they have enemies, did they owe money, did anybody ever notice someone watching the house?
So far they are Mr. and Miss Normal.
(backing away) If you find anything, call, it might help me. He's gone.
I received a subpoena from your husband's lawyer for your work records, where you were, date and times for the past two years.
That's blackmail.
Almost three quarters of your cases are current. I can't let that information go into open court. So until you settle your divorce, I'm going to have to put you on a desk.
That's also blackmail.
That's one of your big problems, Atwood, you don't know how to ask for help.
Do you know what he did to me?
You can't grow old as a woman without having at least one lousy man in your life.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD

I was so stupid. While we were married, while I paid for him to live, the son of a bitch fucked every woman he could get his hands on. He fucked my friends, he even fucked a cousin of mine. Everyone knew but me, and they were laughing at me behind my back. He made me look like an idiot. I was a joke. CAPTAIN LISTER
And?... DETECTIVE ATWOOD
And what? CAPTAIN LISTER
Get over it. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I made him an offer. I'm not going to give him one red cent more. CAPTAIN LISTER
I hear what he's asking for, you could take out of pocket change. Do that and go on with your life. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I couldn't live with myself if I did. CAPTAIN LISTER
I'll spread your work among the other guys and the FBI will be here on thursday... (motions to the pictures) ... they'll take over this case. DETECTIVE ATWOOD

Please, these are my cases. Nobody knows them like me. Don't give them away and don't give the Thumbprint Killer to the FBI. He's killed people in twelve other states, let them fuck up those investigations. This one's mine.
CAPTAIN LISTER
(opening the door to leave) You heard Meeks escaped? DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Yeah. CAPTAIN LISTER
Do you want a detail on you in case he comes after you? DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I can take care of myself. CAPTAIN LISTER
You're a good cop, Tracy, I don't want to lose you, but you have to help me if you want me to help you.

head_text.subj: INT. HALLWAY N CRIME LAB N AFTERNOON

text: Atwood is waiting for an elevator. It arrives. The doors open. The car is empty.

Atwood gets in and presses the key for her destination, t slumps into a corner for the ride. The doors close. The elevator begins to move. All at once Atwood screams. Her pent-up anger and frustra rip the air and she goes nuts. She punches the wall of the elevator, kicks it, throws herself to the other side, bangs her head against that wa punches it, kicks it, all the while screaming. Then the tears come. The screams stop and she settles upr against the back wall, where she strikes her chest repeat with the flat of her closed hand. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
What is wrong with me? What is wrong with me? What is wrong with me?
It's raining. The yellow Police tape that still circles t yard snaps in the wind.

Up the driveway, out of sight of all the other homes, the a movement at the side door of the house. A closer inspection reveals that it's Detective Atwood. F under her umbrella she studies her surroundings and as if she's speaking to the killer, she speaks to herself.

Did you choose them because of where they lived or how they looked or what jobs they had? Or did you just pick them because at the instant you saw them, you had decided to kill someone? The side door was perfect. No one could see you pick the lock. With a key she lets herself in.

Parked against the curb opposite the driveway of the Murd House is an old green Pontiac Convertible with the top up The driver's window is down and from inside a WOMAN, late 20's, is watching the house.
Atwood stops in the PANTRY almost in the exact spot where Brooks stopped. The quiet is filled by the rain drumming on the roof. The wind rattles the windows.
How did you know where they were in the house? She steps into the KITCHEN. On the way across she bumps i a chair.

It's darker tonight than it was on your night. But still how did you manage not to bump into the furniture? Did you have a little light? That would be too dangerous. I'll bet you were in the house before.

So I should ask the neighbors if they saw a meter reader around the house or a telephone repairman or someone from the gas company. These musings take her through the LIVING ROOM to the entrance of the HALLWAY where she pauses and looks both w

Once again, how did you know where they were? Did you check the rooms before you found them? She had his semen in her vagina, they had just made love, did you hear them or was there a light on? She steps into the HALL.
And when did you bag the gun? Because even though I'm sure you're an expert at it, there's still a chance of noise from the plastic. She continues down the HALL to the BEDROOM.
Was the door open or did you have to open it? She opens the door and goes in.
Were they asleep or awake? Was the light on, or did you turn it on? Because I know you, you wouldn't risk a shot in the dark. She turns on the overhead light.

Too bright. What if it wasn't that light that was on, but this one? She turns on a bedside light and goes back to the door an turns off the overhead. If the dance Couple were on the bed and their blood was n on the wall, the room would look exactly the way it did w Mr. Brooks said 'hello'.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD

That's better... What thrill do you get by killing people? Is it sexual, is it hate, is it power? Do you feel remorse? Probably that part of your brain doesn't exist. Do you have emotions of love or affection or joy? Or have you learned to fake them so you won't stand out in a crowd. She's at the window now, feeling the curtains. DETECTIVE ATWOOD

What if these are stuck closed because you yanked them closed? Which means they were open when you came into the room. She separates the fabric and looks out the rain-streaked window at the four story building across the alley. There lights on in almost all the apartment windows. DETECTIVE ATWOOD

If Mr. and Miss Normal made love with the curtains open and the lights on, someone in that building noticed them and may have seen you. She allows the fabric to drop back into place and turns t look at the bed. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Was that what you were angry about?
Moving slowly across a neutral colored wall. DETECTIVE ATWOOD (O.S.)

Thank you for your time. A door is closed. We come to the corner and are looking d a HALLWAY at Atwood coming toward us. We move to her and arrive just as she raises her fist to knock. Before she can, the door opens and she and Mr. Smith who on his way out of his Apartment are surprised that the ot one is suddenly there. Each one takes a half step back. Phwap! The manila envelope that was wedged under Mr. Smit left arm hits the floor.
Oh! You scared me.
I'm sorry... (bends down and picks up the envelope)
... I was about to knock. I'm Detective Atwood with the Chicago Police.
(accepting the envelope) Thank you. Through the open door, Atwood can see Mr. Smith's camera table and the collapsed tripod leaning against the wall.
Are you a photographer... (glances at her list) Mr. Baffert?
No... eh, it's kind of a hobby, I just started.
I don't know if you're aware but there was a murder...
Oh, yes in the house across the alley...
Did you happen to see anything unusual or suspicious that night around that house? Anything at all? Mr. Smith puts on his thinking expression and pauses a li bit before:
No... I wondered that when I heard what happened, but... no. (looks at his watch) I'm sorry, I'm meeting someone and I don't want to be late. He moves into the Hallway closing the door behind him.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Here's my card, if you hear anything or remember anything. MR. SMITH

(taking the card) I wish I could be of more help, but sorry. Watching him walk away amid the crinkle of his raincoat, Detective Atwood, maybe because of her woman's intuition maybe because she's a good cop, wonders what is in that manila envelope under his arm. The thought is gone almost as soon as it comes and she fa about to the next door.

Hunched against the rain, Mr. Smith is acutely aware of t traffic. His eyes strain to see the Occupants of each pas car. He doesn't give a second thought to the older non- descript Toyota parked against the far curb.
Mr. Brooks is in the driver's seat. Marshall is in the ba They're both tracking the progress of Mr. Smith. MR. BROOKS
He looks clean. He looks like he's alone. MARSHALL
No, I'm telling you he wants to do this. MR. BROOKS
I guess I should turn around and go pick him up. MARSHALL
Nah. Just honk. Maybe he'll get killed crossing the street and save us the mess of doing it.
Honk!! Honk!! Mr. Smith looks around. He's not sure that sound was for him. But when the Toyota honks again and flashes it's lights, Mr. Smith waves and splashes to the center of the street.
Even though he stops to let it pass, a car sounds its hor and swerves to avoid him. Mr. Smith crosses behind the To and opens the passenger door.
Mr. Smith flops into the seat.
Woof! It's really coming down out there.
They say it'll be sunny tomorrow. Mr. Smith fumbles with the buttons and zipper on his raincoat.
I never trust those guys, when they say it's going to be clear it always rains and when they say it's going to rain, it's sunny. He comes up with the manila envelope.
Here's what you asked for. Mr. Brooks takes it and hefts it.
The pictures and the memory card all here?
Yeah.
You and I both know that not all the pictures are in here and you made a copy of the Memory Card, isn't that so?
But you understand my position. Mr. Brooks favors him with a wolfish smile.
Yes, I do. But it's my hope that once you get to know me better you'll feel comfortable in giving me all that I've asked for.
That sounds fair. Oh, I almost forgot. I thought you might be interested in this. His hand comes forward with a card.
It's the policewoman who's looking for you. Marshall snaps forward from the back seat.
Wow! We've never known anyone who's looking for us before. Mr. Brooks pinches the rectangle of paper away from Mr. S for a closer view.
We've got to find out everything there is to know about this woman.
This is too close, Marshall, too damn close. Mr. Smith interrupts Mr. Brooks's focus on Detective Atwo card.
So, what do we do now? What's the plan for the evening? Mr. Brooks slips the envelope under the seat and starts t car.
We drive around until we see someone we think we might enjoy killing.
Really? That's it? I thought you might already have someone in mind.
MR. BROOKS

I don't enjoy this, Mr. Smith. I do it because I'm addicted to it. And before you entered my life I had vowed I would never kill again. So this is your party, you can chose anyone you want and we'll do it together. MR. SMITH
Can it be someone I know? MR. BROOKS
You never kill someone you know. That's the easiest way to get caught.
The Toyota enters the traffic.
An older WOMAN in a Stewardess uniform is standing in the doorway of her apartment. Atwood is in front of her in th HALL. STEWARDESS
I wasn't in town that night, my roommate was, maybe he saw something. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
May I speak to him? STEWARDESS
He's on his way to Tokyo now, he's also a Flight Attendant. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Did the victims ever leave the curtains in the bedroom open? STEWARDESS
All the time. I don't know if they thought we couldn't see them "fucking" or they didn't care.
Here's my card, could you ask your roommate to call me when he gets back, the people at that number will find me any hour of the day or night.
I won't be here, but I'll leave him a note.
Mr. Brooks' Toyota is cruising in the flow of traffic.
... maybe I already know how to pick the locks on the house, if I don't...
... I buy one of those locks and I practice on it, same with the alarm... some I know how to bypass, some I have to study.
You don't mind me asking these questions?
No. This is your first time, you're interested. And you should be if you're... A neutral-colored PICKUP swerves out of the next lane int Mr. Brooks' lane.

Jesus Christ!! Mr. Brooks is forced to slam on his brakes to avoid runni up the PICKUP'S tailpipe. HOONKK!!! Mr. Brooks angrily lays on the horn. The brake lights of the PICKUP flash in response causing Brooks to brake again.
Fuck him!! It was his fault!! What an asshole!!
(leans forward) Maybe Mr. Smith would like to kill the driver of the pickup.
(to Mr. Smith) What about the driver of the pickup? What if we killed him?
Oh, fuck, yes!! I've always wanted to kill someone who fucked with me in traffic. The PICKUP makes a right onto a side street. Mr. Brooks follows.
Do you want to kill the driver of the pickup or the owner, they may not be the same.
The driver.
Okay we'll follow until we get a look at him, or her; would it bother you to kill a woman?
No. An asshole's an asshole. Mr. Brooks begins to slow down.
What are you doing?
The asshole shouldn't know we've decided to follow him, or her.
Detective Atwood is on her way out the Outer Door when th hair on the back of her neck stands on end.

Footsteps can be heard running toward her through the rai Her hand goes under her jacket and comes out holding a Gl 9mm. She sidesteps out of the light into the grayness at the e of the doorway. Now she sees the RUNNER. A hood hides the face. She can't tell if it's a Man or a Woman. Detective Atwood thumbs the Glock's safety to the 'off' position. The Runner passes, white breath coming from an unseen mou She waits while the Figure recedes, then with the gun sti in hand she fishes into a pocket for a cell phone and hea in the opposite direction. A finger speedials a number. After a second ring a:
(answers)
Yes?
(puts the phone to her ear)
It's Tracy. Can you carve out some time for me tonight?... I'll be home in an hour and a half. I'll see you there. The phone is shut, the umbrella unfurled and the darkness swallows her up.
The neutral-colored Pickup is parked in front. The DRIVER gets out.

It has stopped at the curb just beyond the Entrance to th Mini-Mart parking lot. Mr. Brooks and Mr. Smith watch the DRIVER come around the front of another car before entering the store. The light reveals the Driver to be a tall middle-age prep guy with close cropped dark hair and dark-rimmed glasses.
Would you recognize him if you saw his driver's license picture?
Yeah.
I've memorized the license number, you write it down. When you get home go on the Internet and find out everything you can about this guy.
We aren't going to kill him tonight?
No. We could, but then we wouldn't be in control. We could leave loose ends, and we both know the danger of that.
(squints at the Pickup's license)
I got it.
Look at me. Mr. Smith does.
Close your eyes. What's the number?
VF... eh... Mr. Smith opens his eyes and grins sheepishly.
Don't feel bad, I've been doing this a long time... (he points to a holder on the dash)
Pen, paper. Write it down.
(copying the number) What was your first time?
MR. BROOKS
You really don't want to know that much about me, Mr. Smith.

The lane lines are in place. Detective Atwood is the only one in the water. Up and dow she goes with a long smooth stroke flipping the turns. Sh not swimming for pleasure, she's working out. The underwater lights cast rippling shadows on the walls ceiling and since they are the only illumination, the roo feels spooky. Atwood's fingers touch the wall. She raises her head to c her time, then takes off her goggles. Hanging onto the gutter she tries to catch her breath, lo herself under the surface, blows a lungful of bubbles, co up to face LARRY, a Man slightly younger than she is, in beautiful suit, perched on the edge of the deck looking d at her. He has a dress on a hangar over one shoulder and a pair o shoes dangling from the fingers of his other hand. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Hi. LARRY
Hi. I brought a dress and a pair of shoes. I thought we could leave from here. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Great idea. She lifts herself to him and they kiss.

head_text.subj: INT. EXCLUSIVE SUPPER CLUB N NIGHT

text: Detective Atwood and Larry are at a balcony table overloo a well-populated dance floor. The Music is 40's and 50's performed by a live BAND. LARRY
... I gave him my driver's license, my student ID, he didn't look anything like me, luckily they never checked.
I did something like that except I was the one who took the test. It wasn't math, a friend of mine was a theology major and needed a second language to get into the Master's program...
She started her career in theology with a lie?!
Isn't that what all theology is based on?
Did you pass the test?
Oh yeah...
Don't tell me she ended up as Mother Teresa or the Pope.
No, she realized very quickly there wasn't enough money in religion for her, the last I heard she'd written a diet book that was very successful.

She stayed in religion. Atwood smiles, her fingers find Larry's and they intertwi The view floats over the balcony. As it slowly drops, the PEOPLE on the dance floor, Couple Couple, disappear until there are only three Couples left one of them is Atwood and Larry. Her head is on his shoul It's a slow dance. Larry is very good and wherever he leads, Atwood easily follows. The lights begin to dim and we move in. Larry touches his lips to Atwood's neck. She arches back he kisses her neck again and again.

His lips move up and find hers, and we are now close on t kiss. Gently the lips separate and we slowly retreat. Looking into her eyes, Larry traces her lips with a finge then replaces that finger with his tongue. His lips brush a cheek, down her neck to where it meets h shoulder, his teeth close softly on the muscle, by now we far enough away to realize that Atwood and Larry have no clothes on and we are:

What light there is, is coming from a room we can't see. Larry nibbles at Atwood collarbone, kisses a breast, stro his hands down her sides. She shivers. He brushes his lip back and forth across her stomach and then down to where flesh of her belly meets her pubic hair. She's watching all of this in a mirror on the opposite wa Then he sinks to his knees and buries his head between he legs. From low in her throat, Atwood moans. We lose sight the Couple as we move around a corner.

It's dark. Atwood is propped up against the headboard, th sheet pulled up over her breasts. The door to the BATHROOM opens. Larry dressed in his suit minus the tie, comes out, kneels on the bed and kisses he LARRY
Thank you, this was wonderful. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
For me too. LARRY
I'll see you then? DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I'd like that. The money is in the usual place. LARRY
It's not just the money, Tracy. I like you.
I like you too, Larry. Send me a bill for the dress and the shoes.
I will. Good-night.
Good-night.

head_text.subj: EXT. MR. BROOKS' CERAMICS STUDIO N NIGHT

text: The rain is muffled by the trees. Move slowly toward the Building then up the side to peek through the narrow window that circles just below the roo line. In the center of the room, the kiln relieves the darkness with a yellow red glow whose rim touches a slash of white light coming from under a door tucked in a corner.

We creep through the white light across the floor that's littered with splashes of paint and smears of clay to the office door and peer under it. In front of us are chair casters and two bare feet and le
I think that was right. Go back.
We're in.
With the taxes we pay, you'd think they could make it more difficult to hack into the Police personnel files. We tip toe under the door.
It's crammed with file cabinets. Sketches for pottery pie are taped to the walls along with photos of Mr. Brooks, J and Emma.

Mr. Brooks, clad only in a T-shirt and underwear, is sitt in front of a computer. Marshall, dressed as he usually i is in a chair at his side. They are both staring at the monitor where on one side of screen is Detective Atwood's Police ID photo, on the othe side of the screen, Mr. Brooks is scrolling through her personnel file.
.... Huh... her father's Gerald Atwood, why does that ring a bell?
Someone you did business with, someone we killed?

Not someone we killed... MBA... College of William and Mary... she's been a cop for eleven years... Married Doctor Carlson, divorced Dr. Carlson, married Jesse Vialo... restaurateur... separated from Jesse Vialo, sued for support by Jesse Vialo, seeing a shrink because of Jesse Vialo...
Excellent fitness report though.
She caught the Hangman, the guy that escaped the other day...
Oooh... She's caught a lot of people... And look here, this isn't the first time she's been hunting for us.
I wonder what the deal was with her and Jesse Vialo? Mr. Brooks taps a key that minimizes Atwood's file then d it to the right hand corner. In the middle of a key strok hits him:
MR. BROOKS

Ahhhh... now I remember. Her father, Gerald Atwood, never did business with him but Emma and I met him a couple times, big political fundraiser. He owns or owned one of the largest insurance groups in the country and a lot of other stuff. Tap, tap, tap. Jesse Vialo's Driver's license comes up. MR. BROOKS
Jesse Vialo... Good looking, a little younger than she is. MARSHALL
Younger, restaurateur... (snorts) She married him on the rebound from the doctor and I'll bet he married her for her money and her connections. MR. BROOKS
The old man being rich doesn't mean she's rich. Maybe he's one of those guys who would rather give it to the Opera than to his kids. MARSHALL
Wouldn't she have to declare any outside income and holdings to the Police? MR. BROOKS
Hmmm... He restores Atwood's file. Tap, tap, tap, tap. Stop. The study the screen then look at each other. MR. BROOKS
The Opera didn't get much. MARSHALL
Why would a woman with her education and worth 60 plus million dollars and probably more to come, want to be a cop? MR. BROOKS
I like that about her.
MARSHALL
You're such a fucking snob, Earl. You like her because she's rich. MR. BROOKS
No, I like her because she found something that's hers. It's not the family business. And she's good at it. I'd like Jane to find something that's hers and that she could be good at. MARSHALL
That's exactly why Atwood scares the shit out of me. She's a cop who doesn't need the money and she's looking for us. That's one fucking dangerous human being. MR. BROOKS
The fact that you're not wrong doesn't make me admire her any less.
At a table the Asian Attorney is going over a brief. Ther are two foamy coffees in to-go cups in front of her. Detective Atwood arrives at the table. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Hi... She reaches out, the Women shake hands. ASIAN ATTORNEY
Hi. I got you a Latte. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(sitting) Thanks and thanks for meeting me here. ASIAN ATTORNEY
We got an injunction to quash the subpoena for your work records yesterday. They've already appealed. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
That doesn't help me does it?
Your father has a lot of political muscle.
My father does nothing for nothing.
I understand. If you're willing to play the game and ride a desk for a year; I think we can settle for one two five, one five.
No desk.
Then the only other option is money. Tell me how high you are willing to go.
One five.
I can try. If I were on the other side I'd hold out for more.
How much more?
Give me a cap and that's how high we'll go.
Try and get a number out of them first. I want to know what ballpark I'm playing in and if it's a lump sum, is it less than something that's paid in installments.
I'll call them today. Atwood stands up with her coffee.
I'd like to get this done as soon as possible.
The Asian Attorney also stands and gathering her papers a coffee. ASIAN ATTORNEY
Are you working on the Thumbprint Killer this time?
Yeah. ASIAN ATTORNEY

That one's creepy to me. The doors are locked, the alarms are armed and the people are dead. It makes you feel like you're not safe anywhere. Atwood nods and opens the front door then follows the Attorney out.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Where are you parked? ASIAN ATTORNEY
I'm right over there. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I'm down the street. Call me as soon as you have something. She starts to walk away. ASIAN ATTORNEY
Oh, Tracy... I almost forgot, your husband says there's a picture of him holding some trophy that you still have. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
He took all those pictures. He took everything. ASIAN ATTORNEY
He claims it's his favorite picture and you put it up where you store your suitcases.
I'll look.
I know it's petty, but you're going through a divorce.

Atwood strides toward her car. The PEDESTRIAN traffic is light. It's too early for the stores to be open. Up ahead a BROWN VAN is idling at the curb, the sliding s door is open. Atwood can see inside. Empty except for som furniture blankets. The Person in the Driver's seat turns to look into the ba It's the Woman who was watching Atwood outside the Murder House. Her hands are unseen in leather gloves. She looks up and their eyes meet. Two strangers. The cont is instantly broken. Atwood takes a deep breath and smiles. After the rain, th air is brisk and clean. It's good to be alive. SLAM!!! Atwood is body-checked by a Man who springs out o the recess of a doorway. His arms wrap around her, she's lifted off her feet and the Man throws himself and her in the Van.

Oooff!! The wind is knocked out of Atwood when she lands shoulder first on the furniture blankets, the Man on top her. The Man is Thorton Meeks, the Hangman, six feet, a solid hundred pounds. He's also wearing tight leather gloves.
The Brown Van accelerates fast away from the curb.
His body crushing hers, Meeks kisses Atwood's cheek.
Surprise, surprise, Tracy. I told you I was coming back to get you. He frees his right hand and pulls his gun.

I already know where I'm gonna hang you. But first I'm gonna watch her... (indicates the Driver) ... have some fun with you, then she's gonna watch me have some fun with you. He kisses her again and puts the gun to Atwood's head.
Now, don't move. He raises up and straddles her.
You know the drill, I'm gonna put the cuffs on. With his left hand he fishes a pair of handcuffs from a b pocket and snaps them on Atwood's right wrist.

Now the left. He rolls Atwood on her back and with the chain of the handcuff pulls her right arm toward her left. All Meeks' talk has allowed Atwood to catch her breath an suddenly she jerks her head up into the gun and screams a the top of her lungs.

At the same time she pulls hard against the handcuff with right wrist. A startled Meeks is thrown off balance. The comes away from Atwood's head. Her left arm now free, Atwood swings her palm with all of might into Meeks' right ear. POP!! His eardrum breaks. Aaaggh!! He instinctually reaches to cover the damaged ea with his gun hand. The Driver doubles around to see what's happening. From outside, HOONNNKK!! The Driver's attention returns to the road.

Atwood swings again. This time she snags the barrel of th gun and using it as a lever bends Meeks' hand back on the wrist. BLAM! The gun goes off. Neither one of them is hit. At the same time Atwood pulls hard on the handcuff that M is holding in his left hand and twists into him. This dislodges Meeks and he's off of her. Snarling like animals they fight for the gun. CRACK! Atwood's leverage breaks Meeks' trigger finger. Hi grip loosens on the weapon. She pulls it out of his hand. A quick push skitters it across the floor. It drops throu the open side door into the street. Atwood rolls away and reaches for her ankle gun. Now it's Meeks' turn. A sharp tug on the chain of the handcuff sta her motion. He flicks his other arm and a switchblade is delivered in his right hand. Snap!! The blade comes out. Atwood is reaching again for her ankle gun. She sees the flash of m and flings her head back. Luckily all she receives is a deep gash above her right e Blood immediately begins to cascade over her brow. Meeks grins and gives another sharp tug on the handcuff t pull Atwood into the range of his knife. With one foot Atwood kicks at him, with the other she pus off and propels herself backward to grab a handful of the Driver's hair. Atwood's weight hinges the Driver's head back until she's looking at the ceiling. Her scream is equal parts pain an surprise.
The Brown Van veers into the on-coming traffic. The Drive the car dead ahead swerves. The Van solidly clips the rea that car.
The sudden deceleration of that impact slingshots Atwood Meeks forward. She hits the back of the Driver's seat.
Meeks has further to go. He loses his hold on the handcuf and smashes into the passenger seat. Her right hand now free, Atwood scratches for the gun on hip.
Careening across its lane, the Van sideswipes a parked ca

That impact rips Atwood's hand out of the Driver's hair a sends her sliding on her knees toward the side door. On her way she unclips her gun and is bringing it out of holster when Meeks who has managed to hang onto the passe seat sees this and slams a foot into her chest. Atwood is launched backward out the side door.

In slow motion Atwood flies through the air while at norm speed the Van is leaving her behind. SMASH! Butt first, Atwood hammers into the back window of parked car. The shattering glass breaks her fall. Groggily she rolls out of the indentation. Gun still in h and blood covering one side of her face she slides off th car to stand in the street. The Van is nowhere in sight.
Captain Lister is watching a DOCTOR sew up the gash on Detective Atwood's forehead.
We found the van in an underground lot about two miles from where they left you. It was stolen last night. Detective Snyder comes in and hands a packet of photograp to Atwood.
These are the women we have pictures of who know Meeks.
Meeks and the Woman, none of the Attendants remember seeing them. As Detective Atwood begins to go through the pictures.
That chiropractor, Alvin Griffin, who sold Meeks his steroids, he might know where he is.
His phone's been tapped since Meeks escaped. No contact that way so far and he's sure not going to talk to us.
What about a warrant to search his house? Get me in the door and he'll talk to me.
How's your divorce going?
I took your advice and told my lawyer to settle. Stretching out her arm to return the photos:
None of these is the woman in the van.
Whoa... I'm sewing up your head here.
Sorry.
And your ego can handle that?
It doesn't like any of the other choices.
Until Meeks is caught, Snyder is with you.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Nothing personal, Snyder. (to Lister) He's not part of our team. CAPTAIN LISTER
He's there to protect you. And listen to him, he's been alive longer than you have. SNYDER
I didn't volunteer for this, Atwood. CAPTAIN LISTER

The Parking Lot has a security camera. We're checking the tape. If Meeks and the Woman left in a car we'll have a license number. You have two days then I want a progress report on your divorce. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I think I have all the pieces on the Thumbprint Killer, I'm just not looking at them the right way. CAPTAIN LISTER
Okay, you have three days. She leaves. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(smiles sweetly at Snyder) Every babysitter I ever had loved me.

head_text.subj: EXT. DRUG STORE PARKING LOT N NIGHT

text: In the scattering of vehicles Mr. Brooks' Toyota is hidde plain sight in a row of cars.

Behind the wheel, Mr. Brooks is again wearing his Pottery Throwing clothes. Mr. Smith is in the passenger seat and Marshall is leaning forward from the back. They're all focused to varying degrees on the Entrance to store. Mr. Smith raises his watch for a look at the time.
Maybe he went home with someone else.
Can you still see his pickup? Mr. Smith looks.
Uh huh.

This is not the kind of guy who leaves his pickup in an unguarded Lot overnight. The silence returns. All three Men idly observe an old green Pontiac convertib with a frayed top and paint peeling, come into the Lot an park two spaces away facing them. We saw this car last watching Atwood from outside the Murder House. The headlights go off. The Driver's door opens. The Woman who was with Meeks in Van steps out and hurries toward the Drug Store. She of course means nothing to Mr. Brooks but in the brie seconds the domelight is on, he catches sight of the Man the passenger seat. A memory tickles his brain. He turns to Marshall.
Where do we know that guy from?
You really should pay more attention to what you read, Earl.
That's what I have you for, Marshall.
His picture was on the front page of the paper a couple days ago because he escaped from jail. He's the killer they call the Hangman.
MR. BROOKS
Ahh... MARSHALL
Remember that cop you like, Atwood, who's chasing us, she's the one who put him away. I think his name is Thorton Meeks. Mr. Brooks cocks his head at the vague outline of Meeks. MR. BROOKS
Well, well, well... What would life be without surprises? Mr. Smith who, remember, cannot hear or see Marshall, straightens up. MR. SMITH
There he is! The Man they are waiting for is coming down the steps of store. On the way to his Pickup he takes off a Manager's smock. MR. SMITH

You know what's weird? I'll bet he has all these plans of what he's going to do tonight and tomorrow and he doesn't know he will already be dead and won't be able to do any of them. Mr. Brooks nods absently. The Drug Store Manager arrives his truck. MR. BROOKS
I don't think I want to kill this guy. MR. SMITH
What?! But you promised we would! Marshall smiles. MARSHALL
Oh, I love what you're thinking. MR. BROOKS
You have no idea what I'm thinking.
MARSHALL
Oh yes I do, and it's wonderfully twisted. MR. BROOKS
(to Mr. Smith) I know I said we would, but I don't think it would be that much fun. Mr. Brooks starts the car and puts it in reverse. MR. SMITH
So just like that, you're saying 'no', it's not going to happen. MR. BROOKS
Yes. MR. SMITH
(purses his lips into a tight line) I see. Mr. Brooks casts his eyes on the license plate of the car Meeks is in. MARSHALL
You get the number? MR. BROOKS
I got it.

head_text.subj: EXT. DRUG STORE PARKING LOT N NIGHT

text: Mr. Brooks' Toyota leaves.
Mr. Smith sits stiffly. His expression hasn't changed. MARSHALL
Mr. Smith wants you to notice he's pouting. MR. BROOKS
Yeah, I know.
The Toyota is part of the light traffic.
The Toyota comes into view around a corner and stops next the sidewalk.
MR. BROOKS
I know you're upset, Mr. Smith, and I'm sorry. MR. SMITH
Yeah, I am upset. MR. BROOKS

Maybe I was a little abrupt back there, but let me explain. Finding someone you think would be fun to kill is a bit like falling in love. You meet a lot of candidates, and you like some of them and they're nice, but they're not right; and then that special one shows up and your heart beats faster and you know that's the one. The man in the pickup did not make my heart beat faster. MR. SMITH
Okay, he did not make your heart beat faster. If not him, who? MR. BROOKS
I don't know, I think I have someone in mind. MR. SMITH
Do you need me to do any work on it? MR. BROOKS
No, let's see how it plays out. MR. SMITH

You see? That's my problem. That makes me feel like I'm being jerked around, Mr. Brooks. I thought it was happening last night, then it was happening tonight. And now it's "Let's see how it plays out". (MORE)
I feel like you're planning to back out on our deal and I don't like that feeling at all.
I promise you, it will happen.
When? That's what I want to know, Mr. Brooks. When?
Tomorrow night, same time. When you come out of your building, turn right, go to the first street you can go west on, I'll pick you up on that street.
Okay. He gets out and with the door still open, turns back.
I want to do this. But if it drags on too long, I could change my mind.
Don't you think I want to do this, Mr. Smith?
Maybe you don't anymore. He shuts the door. Marshall and Mr. Brooks watch him walk away.
Even if that guy was charming and funny I still wouldn't like him.
The Toyota U-turns, makes the corner and is lost from sig
The garage door opens and Mr. Brooks swings the Toyota inside.
Mr. Brooks steps out of the Toyota onto a sheet of plasti Two strides away is an industrial vacuum cleaner.
Mr. Brooks vacuums the passenger seat and dash and floor everything around it.

Mr. Brooks removes his shoes and leaves them on the plast then slips his feet into paper slippers. With handiwipes he wipes down the outside of the passenge door, in fact anything on that side Mr. Smith could have touched. He opens the door and wipes down the seat and the dash an the console. Back on the plastic, Mr. Brooks undresses. On top of his clothes he drops the used handiwipes, the slippers and th vacuum bag. The corners of the plastic sheet are folded up, twisted together and Zip-tied to create a nice neat package which Brooks picks up and takes into the Ceramics Studio.
Mr. Brooks rinses off the lather under the spray.
The glow from 3000 degrees Fahrenheit is coming through t window of the kiln.

The Driver's license, complete with picture, of the Woman was with Meeks in the Drug Store parking lot, is up on th computer screen. Mr. Brooks, now back in his regular clothes, brings the cursor down to the address. He scores this and drags it i Yahoo Maps 'driving directions'. A route is generated. Mr. Brooks brings the cursor up to 'Print' and clicks.
CLOSE on his Printer. The map is fed out and settles into tray.

An unmarked Police car stops on the gravel of the Turn- Around. Two Plainclothes DETECTIVES get out and walk to t front door. The taller One rings the bell and they wait and then the is opened by Mr. Brooks. In a flash he takes in the car and the way the Men are dressed and although his face doesn't betray it, he knows what they are.
Hi, what can I do for you? The shorter One holds up a badge.
I'm Detective Smolny with the Chicago Police and this is Detective Carfagno, from Palo Alto, California...
(showing his badge) We'd like to speak to Jane Brooks, if that's possible.
Jane is my daughter, what's this about?
There was a murder at Stanford not long before she left. She may be able to help us.
Is she a suspect?
Not at this time. We simply would like to ask her some questions.
Is your daughter here?
Yes... she is.
The questions won't take long.
I'm sure you would have no objection if she had an attorney present.
That's fine. (reaching into his pocket) Here's my card. We can schedule a time for later today or tomorrow for her to come in to see us. Mr. Brooks looks at the card.
If you gentlemen can wait, I will call my lawyer right now and see what we can work out.
Oh, that's even better.
(opening the door wider) Would you like some coffee?
Thank you.
Marshall is walking alongside a very disturbed Mr. Brooks
We both knew she was hiding something bigger, I certainly didn't think it was this big.
She's not a suspect, Marshall. She may not have anything to do with it at all. Mr. Brooks opens a door. The room that is revealed is a v well equipped home GYM.
In sweats and wearing a Walkman, Emma is working out on a Elliptical machine. Mr. Brooks motions to her that he wants to talk. Emma tak off the headphones and pauses the machine.
Did Jane ever tell you that there was a murder at her school?
No.
Nothing? Not that a friend died or someone she knew died? Or someone in her dorm died?
No.
There are two Detectives downstairs, one is from Palo Alto, they want to ask her some questions about a murder that occurred shortly before she came home.
Oh, my Gosh! I'm sure if she was close to someone who was murdered, she would have said something.
I called Roger, he suggested a criminal attorney, they'll be here within the hour.
I'll get dressed.
There are now three cars plus the unmarked Police car in Turn-Around.
Everyone is in the LIVING ROOM.

Jane is on a couch flanked by her Mother and a LAWYER. Standing behind them is a heavyset LAWYER and a YOUNG LAW We've never seen any of these Men before. Facing this Group from the opposite couch are the two Detectives. There are two tape recorders on the coffee ta Mr. Brooks is in a chair off to one side watching everyth For him the conversation is merely a burble of voices. He studies his daughter while she answers a question. She is unaware of his scrutiny. And finally all he can se are her lips moving. Even the burble has faded to silence

The unmarked Police car with the two Detectives pulls awa We move in on the front door. It opens. The Lawyers spill out. Mr. Brooks shakes hands with the lawyer who was sitt on the couch next to Jane.
Mr. Clifford, it was a pleasure. Thank you for coming on such short notice.
There won't be any more dropping by like they did today, they'll call us first.
Thanks again, Roger. It was a good idea to hear what they wanted to know sooner rather than later.
We'll talk.
Yup. He waves and re-enters the house.

Mr. Brooks shuts the door and turning, finds himself face face with Emma and Jane. The Women are both worried. He and his Daughter look at each other. For a brief insta each one tries to find what they hope to find in the othe
Mr. Brooks smiles and folds the Girl into his arms.
You did good, Kid. Your answers were clear, concise and honest. And when they tried to trip you up, it didn't work.
I hope so. I'm not feeling so well.
Should you lie down?
I think I'd better. Mr. Brooks kisses his daughter on the top of the head.
Try and get some sleep. Jane bends her steps toward the stairs.

(to Emma) I think Roger has a handle on this. He and Mr. Clifford will take care of it. Emma takes her Husband's hand and after squeezing it foll her Daughter. On the stairs Jane stops and looks back.

I'm sorry I didn't tell you about it, Daddy. It was horrible but I really didn't know the guy that well. It happened at about the same time I found out I was pregnant, and it just went out of my mind.
I understand. Jane resumes her journey up the stairs.
CLOSE on a water glass being filled from a tap.
MR. BROOKS (V.O.)
God grant me the Serenity to accept the things I cannot change, Courage to change the things I can, and Wisdom to know the difference...
With a shaky hand, Mr. Brooks raises the glass to his lip MR. BROOKS
God help me. What do I do? Sitting on the island behind him Marshall waits for Mr. Brooks to gulp the glass dry. MARSHALL
She did it, didn't she? MR. BROOKS
Yeah. It'll take the Cops a week to ten days to put their case together and then they'll come back and arrest her. MARSHALL
What are you going to do? Mr. Brooks puts his hands over his eyes and sobs, then wi away the tears: MR. BROOKS
I've been afraid of this since the day she was born. She has what I have. MARSHALL

Yes, she does. But you've always been smart about it. She was stupid. She did it because she got off on it, she did it for fun. Why didn't she think it through? A hatchet! And she left it there!! MR. BROOKS
They were pretty graphic, weren't they? MARSHALL
That was to shock her into making a mistake.
What does she think I think? Doesn't she remember what she told me? That the BMW was being driven across country by a friend and now right in front of me, she tells the Cops it was stolen.
You've always cleaned up after her, whatever she did, all her life.
If the BMW has anything incriminating in it, I hope it was stolen or she dropped it at the bottom of a very deep lake.
Do you think she knows what kind of trouble she's in?

I think she thought she had gotten away with it until the Cops showed up. I should have listened to her, it was there. She was telling me. 'I didn't quit school because I was pregnant'. I should have dug deeper.
And where would you be but at the exact same place you are now. It is not your fault, Earl. Part of your problem with her is that you always think it is.
She has what I have, Marshall. So on a very basic level, it is my fault.
What are you going to do?
Maybe the best thing for her would be to let her go to jail.
And what about her child?
