MR. BROOKS
Emma and I would raise it. MARSHALL
You might be right, Earl, you might be. Because you know if she's not stopped, she's going to do it again. And if she wants to take over the box business, the next victim could be you. MR. BROOKS
I don't think she'd go that far.
A slide of what looks like enlarged grains of sand among giant carpet fibers is projected onto a screen. The Lead Crime Lab Technician: SIGY (O.S.)

We found traces of this in two places. The slide changes to an overhead schematic showing the interior of the house where the dance Couple was murdered Detective Atwood and Detective Snyder are standing with S watching the presentation. Atwood has a bandage covering stitches over her eye. SIGY
(with a laser pointer) Here and here. The red dot indicates an area just outside the Kitchen an just outside the Bedroom. SIGY
We did an analysis and it's made up of feldspar, alumina and kaolin. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
What's that? SIGY
A high fire stoneware clay. SNYDER
Like you make ashtrays and vases from?
This is more plates and teacups. It was slightly wet when whoever it was tracked it into the house and it stuck to the carpet fibers. We're thinking it was the killer.
It could have been tracked in by a friend.
That's the thing, you see, the friend would have had to have been there almost at the same time the killer was. Otherwise the samples would have been dry and the killer would have vacuumed them up.
Is the clay rare, is it difficult to get?
You can buy it almost anywhere.
That's not much help, Sigy.
And this is the only incongruity you were able to find in the whole house.
We've done everything we know how to do. It sure doesn't break the case wide open, does it?.
No, Sigy, it doesn't. It does give me an excuse to ask someone some new questions.

location: MR. BROOKS' OFFICE N BROOKS BOX FACTORY

text: Mr. Brooks is standing behind his desk staring blankly at contents of his briefcase when Sunday, his Secretary, com in.
Yes, Mr. Brooks?
Mr. Brooks doesn't immediately answer her, he's lost in thought.
(from the couch) Before you open your mouth, be very sure this is the right thing to do.
I will never be sure. Remember; Sunday can neither see nor hear Marshall.
You get pissed at me because I'm always the one arguing to go ahead and do murder. Not this time, Earl. This is your decision.
I know it's wrong. In my heart I know it's wrong.
Then don't do it. Go with Mr. Smith tonight and end that, then let the Police put Jane in jail. Hopefully that will save her and we can happily go on with our tortured lives.
That's exactly what I want to do. That's exactly what I should do. The thing is, she's my daughter and I love her. Mr. Brooks raises his head and looks at Sunday.
I'm going home. Cancel everything for the rest of the day. I might be in tomorrow afternoon. I'll let you know about that.
I'll take care of it.
If you need me, need me, call my studio, that's where I'll be.
MR. BROOKS (CONT'D)
I probably won't pick up, just leave a message. SUNDAY
I'll try not to bother you. The door closes behind her.

With a hidden lever, Mr. Brooks lowers casters under the and rolls it aside to reveal a Combination Safe imbedded the concrete floor. He spins the dial, opens the Safe and extracts four quadr pocketed plastic sleeves which he lines up in front of himself. Each sleeve contains a Driver's License, two Credit cards cash. The pictures on the Driver's Licenses are of Mr. Brooks, you wouldn't immediately recognize him because of the disguises. As he's trying to decide which of the four Identities wou be best for what he has in mind, Marshall comes forward t look over his shoulder. MARSHALL

The thing that bothers me about this, besides the fact we're not prepared, and a multitude of other things, is what does Mr. Smith do when he's walking west tonight and you don't show up. That little freak could flip out. Mr. Brooks chooses the first sleeve and the third sleeve. other two go back into the Safe. MR. BROOKS
I'll take care of it on the way to the airport.

head_text.subj: EXT. FIVE STORY GLASS BUILDING N DAY

text: It's in an Industrial Park. Mr. Smith exits one of the doors and continues on into th Parking Lot to a moderately expensive foreign car sitting a space identified by a sign which reads:

Mr. Baffert. He squeezes the 'disarm' button on his key chain. The car chirps twice and he opens the door. Bending his knees to in, he stops. There is a section of Newspaper wedged in the steering wh When his brain unlocks he straightens up and moving only top of his body, makes a quick recon of the surrounding a and his back seat. Nothing threatening seen, he eases into the seat. Slam! T door is closed and locked.

Gingerly, Mr. Smith removes the Newspaper. It folds open. the first page there are words circled in red. As his eyes dart from one to the other we go in close on words and hear Mr. Brooks say them as Mr. Smith finds the
Not - able - to - meet - Mr. Smith turns the page.
- tonight - Do - it - same - Turns the page.
- time - tomorrow - Turns the page.
- night - Don't - be - stupid -. Mr. Smith refolds the Newspaper and throws it at the passenger seat.
Fuck you! He inserts the key into the ignition. RAP-RAP!! There's a sudden sharp KNOCK!!, on the Driver's window.
Mr. Smith levitates off the seat!! Unable to breathe, he turns. Detective Atwood's face lowers into view.
You remember me? All Mr. Smith can do is nod.
Would you step out of the car, please, I want to talk to you.
Atwood steps back as Mr. Smith gets out. Behind her, Detective Snyder is standing next to the Driver's door of un-marked Police car which has blocked Mr. Smith in.
So Mr. Baffert, what is that you have to tell me?
What do you mean? I don't have anything to tell you.
Really? Because I was driving around and I got this sudden feeling that you had something to tell me about the murders.
No. Nothing.
That's disappointing. Because when I left you the last time we talked, I felt I had missed a clue that was right in front of me that would solve this whole case.
I don't know why you would feel that.
Didn't you tell me you were an amateur potter, that you made bowls and vases?
No, I said I was an amateur photographer.
Are you positive? Because we found potter's clay on the carpet of the murder house and I was sure you said to me that you worked with clay, that you made pots.
No. I said my hobby was photography, not pottery.

Maybe that was it. The Stewardess upstairs said the victims kept their curtains open when they made love. Could I see some of the pictures you took of that Couple? Mr. Smith can only stare at Detective Atwood. His Adam's apple moves up and down though he makes no sound. Should or shouldn't he? Finally he throws his arms up in a shrug but in his half- of indecision he happens to spy the Newspaper he tossed a the passenger seat of his car. Part of it is draped over the console. The red circles ar the words on that page jump out at him.
Don't - be - stupid -. Mr. Smith returns his attention to Detective Atwood.

You are harassing me, Detective Atwood. You know very well I'm not a potter and I don't have any pictures! So my feeling is that your feeling is wrong and that you should move your car and let me go home.
What is your job here? What do you do?
MR. SMITH
I'm a mechanical engineer. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
You have to be pretty smart for that, don't you? MR. SMITH
I guess. DETECTIVE ATWOOD

Then be smart, Mr. Baffert. You lied to me right there at the end. I'll be watching you. And when you want to tell me the truth, you know how to get in touch with me. She gives him a dazzling smile. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
See you later, alligator. Atwood walks back to her car and gets in.

head_text.subj: INT. UNMARKED POLICE CAR N DAY

text: DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(under her breath) Goddamit... As Snyder accelerates away he points to the car's compute screen. SNYDER
Captain Lister got us the search warrant for Meeks' Chiropractor. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Good. (shakes her head 'no', frustrated) Goddamit!, that guy knows something... (meaning Mr. Smith) He almost told me and then something happened. SNYDER
You think he did it? DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I don't think it's that simple.
Mr. Smith watches the unmarked police car going away and wipes the sweat out of his hairline.
We're following a STEWARDESS down the aisle. She stops at row and leans over to hand a glass of tomato juice to the Person in the Window Seat. STEWARDESS
Here you are, Sir. Mr. Brooks who now looks like the Man in the picture on t third Driver's license, accepts the drink.
Thank you. He takes a sip and resumes his gaze out the window. MR. BROOKS

(almost inaudible whisper) God grant me the Serenity to accept the things I cannot change, Courage to change the things I can, and Wisdom to know the difference... The earth that he is looking at below is a long way away.

head_text.subj: EXT. REDWOOD CITY N LATE AFTERNOON

text: Come off a sign which reads: STANFORD UNIVERSITY - 2 1/2 miles to an Alamo rental car traveling south on the El Ca Real.

head_text.subj: INT. ALAMO RENTAL CAR N LATE AFTERNOON

text: In his Pottery-Throwing clothes, Mr. Brooks is behind the wheel. There's an Ace Hardware Store bag sitting upright and ope the passenger seat. We peek over the edge of the bag. A brand new hatchet with a gleaming blade sits at the bot Mr. Brooks adjusts the rearview mirror. Marshall is on th passenger side of the back seat. MR. BROOKS
You're awfully quiet back there.
Without any indication he's been addressed, Marshall continues to stare stoically ahead.
The Alamo Rental car carrying Mr. Brooks continues on.

head_text.subj: INT. HIGH CEILING BUNGALOW N NIGHT

text: It's dark. There's barely enough ambient light to see tha are close on the knob of the Front Door. From outside we hear the muffled sound of a Black & Decke cordless drill and the knob begins to vibrate. Someone is drilling the lock. The sound stops. The knob turns. The door opens. A flashl is shone into our face.
Mr. Alvin Griffin, this is the Chicago Police.

head_text.subj: EXT. HIGH CEILING BUNGALOW N NIGHT

text: From the protection of the doorjamb, a very young UNIFORM POLICEMAN is the person shining the flashlight into the house. He's flanked on either side of the door by Detective Atwo and Detective Snyder. The Officer's flashlight illuminates a short ENTRYWAY wit HALL immediately off to the left and the LIVING ROOM fadi into darkness, straight ahead.

(continues) We have a warrant to search your home and premises. We're coming in. Flashlight in her left hand and the Glock in her right, Detective Atwood is the first one across the threshold. She directs the beam at the wall next to the door; finds light switch. Click! Click! Click.
Lights don't work.

She continues to the Hall. The darkness is so oppressive there, it seems that her stream of light must struggle to pierce it. The Room at the end is the KITCHEN. With Snyder hanging in the Entryway to protect her back, Atwood eases the hand with the flashlight around the corn The dishwasher, the sink, the cabinets gleam dully back a her. She steps inside. A debris field of empty pharmaceutical boxes and vials tr away from the Refrigerator. Her flashlight sweeps the rest of the Room. Beyond an ope countertop in the DINING AREA, the light blurs past an ov of white, and then comes back. It's the face of a WOMAN!! Careful of the litter, Atwood moves forward until she can that the Woman is sitting in a chair at the far end of th dining table. Her throat has been cut. Her head is being held upright b her hair which is taped to the back of the chair. She has a pen taped between her fingers, but the Appointm Book in front of her is drenched in blood.
(calls to the darkness in back of her)
We have a dead woman in here. A light and footsteps hurry toward her from the LIVING RO Atwood swings her light at them.
Hey! He squints and turns away.
I thought you were behind me.
The living room is clean.
Atwood swings her light back onto the dead Woman. The combined illumination of the flashlights cause the suppor joists twelve feet up to throw eerie shadows onto the ope ceiling. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Snyder, meet Mona. The Uniformed Policeman comes up beside Atwood. UNIFORMED POLICEMAN
I called it in. The smell of blood and the sight of the carnage is too mu for him. His gorge rises and he gags. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Do that outside. The Officer doesn't have to be told twice. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(to Snyder, re: the body) Meeks did this. SNYDER
I thought Meeks hung people. Atwood retraces her steps in the Kitchen. DETECTIVE ATWOOD

Meeks is a steroid freak. This Refrigerator was always full of steroids. Mona was Alvin Griffin's niece, receptionist, lover and keeper of the keys. She focuses her flashlight on an open padlock dangling fr steel band that runs around the Refrigerator. With the ba of the Glock she opens the door. The only edibles inside are a tomato, half a loaf of brea package of hotdogs and some part of a chicken in a KFC bo The rest of the space is vacant. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Well, the steroids are certainly gone. SNYDER
You think Meeks has Alvin with him?
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Meeks thinks Alvin turned him in. She shuts the Refrigerator. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Let's go see what's in the rest of the house.

Atwood and her flashlight pass us. Three feet to her righ and slightly behind is Snyder and his flashlight. The two Detectives are leaving the Living Room and enteri the HALL toward the bedrooms. The ceiling is low here and feels very claustrophobic. Ahead is a Door painted red. But before they get to it, there's a Room on the right. Snyder shines his light in. It's a BATHROOM. The shower curtain is open. Nobody in th tub. The Door ahead is waiting, but there's another Door on th right. Snyder shines his light in. This one is a Treatment Room with a Therapy table and she of oils and unguents. They've come to the red Door. Atwood will open this one. She turns the knob and pushes. The Door is stuck. She and Snyder exchange a look. Snyder shuffles back half a step and flattens himself aga the wall. He shuts off his flashlight. Atwood takes a deep breath, levers her weight against the door and pushes. There's a sudden Snap! Then the door swings freely open. beam of Atwood's flashlight reveals a large room containi bed, a dresser, a... CREEEKKK!!! The sound is coming from up in the rafters. Atwood whips her flashlight in that direction. For an instant the beam catches a piece of a large shape falling fast right at her.

Then it's lost in the darkness and then picked up again i the reflected light in the Hall. The shape is a naked Man WHACK!! The Man nails Atwood in the shoulder. BANG! Her g goes off. She bounces into the wall and onto her ass. Barely slowed the Man continues in an upward arc. His fee and knees slam into the ceiling. Plaster dust rains. The Man swings back, past Snyder. He's lost in the darkne again. Then he swings back into the light and comes to a just inside the bedroom Door. The Man is hanging from a rope around his neck. He's dead His Body is festooned with syringes stuck into his bare flesh. In fact two of the needles hold a sheet of paper to the M chest. Printed on the paper in big black letters are the words:
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(getting to her feet) Snyder, this is Alvin Griffin.
The gray of dawn is in the sky.

head_text.subj: EXT. O'HARE AIRPORT N PRE DAWN

text: Mr. Brooks, wearing a disguise that makes him look like t picture on the Driver's license in the first plastic slee gets into a Taxi.
The Cab drops Mr. Brooks off in front of a house. Mr. Bro watches the Cab drive away and then with his Carry-On bag starts walking in the opposite direction. He turns a corn
Still on foot, Mr. Brooks arrives at his non-descript Toy There are also neighborhood cars parked along the street. Brooks unlocks his car and throws his Carry-On onto the passenger seat.
Mr. Brooks' Toyota speeds up an on-ramp and joins the lig traffic.
From the back seat Marshall watches Mr. Brooks remove the pieces of his disguise - a wig, a mustache, glasses, and them in the Carry-On. MARSHALL
How do you feel? MR. BROOKS
Dirty. MARSHALL
That's understandable. You've never killed for this reason before. The feeling will go away. MR. BROOKS

I don't think so. It's the whole thing, Marshall. If I could find a way to just disappear, where there was absolutely no trace of me; because eventually I will get caught doing this. And it'll be very embarrassing for me and Emma and Jane. So I've been thinking... is there a way that Mr. Smith could kill me and make me disappear. MARSHALL
Number one, Mr. Smith is not smart enough to do that. Number two, there is no reason, if you're careful, to believe you will ever get caught. MR. BROOKS
I know I will have to plan it for Mr. Smith, but I think that's what I want to do. MARSHALL
I'm not particularly fond of that plan, Earl. Remember if you die, I go with you and I like being alive. I like eating, I like fucking, I like killing.
I have to end it, Marshall. One way or the other. And I think this is the best way.
Well fuck you then.

Long ago this was a nice area. A banner hangs from an old Deco building - ROOMS FOR RENT. Mr. Brooks is walking through the Parking Lot beside the Building. There, as a first car in a double space is the old green Pontiac convertible. It's blocked in by another car. Mr. Brooks sidles between the cars to check the license p against the one in his memory. It's the car Thorton Meeks was in, outside the Drug Store Mr. Brooks walks away.

Mr. Brooks opens the kiln door and removes three pieces embellished with a beautiful yellow glaze. He sets them on a table then takes his Carry-On bag and places it in a ceramic trough which he puts into the kiln The door is shut.
Flame erupts from the gas jets.
The Bathroom door opens. Mr. Brooks, in his pajamas, turn out the light and crosses to the bed. Emma looks up as he pulls back the covers and gets in.
You worked all night.
I had ideas for pots that took too long and the clay kept winning... (he kisses her) I'll be fine.
And there's a yellow Chinese glaze I'm trying to get right... He lays his head on the pillow and is almost instantly asleep.

Reflected in the glass of an open mirrored closet door is tastefully furnished DEN with floor-to-ceiling windows th look out at LAKE MICHIGAN from the 20th floor. An empty suitcase falls into this picture and bounces on carpet. Behind the mirrored door, Detective Atwood is ato stepstool rummaging through the suitcases on the highest shelf. Throughout the Condo there is an incessant ringing of the phones. Another suitcase goes down and Atwood finds what she's looking for - a framed color 8 x 10 photo of her husband, Jesse. He's in a business suit and holding some kind of trophy. The phones stop ringing. Atwood comes down the stepstool, folds it and is carrying back to where it lives when the phones start ringing agai She picks up a cordless in the Den.
Yes?
The Asian Attorney interrupts her sip of coffee.
Hi Tracy, this is Nancy Tang. We received a counter offer. Are you sitting down?
Yeah, go ahead... He can't get that, can he?! INTERCUT with Nancy.
No, my sense of it is by asking for five, they're hoping you'll settle anywhere between two five and three.
Never. How long can you stall them?
They know you want this done quickly, so they're going to expect a quick counter offer.
I need two days. Wait two days before getting back to them. If they call, tell them it's a big number, I'm thinking about it.
Okay.

And the picture he wanted... She slams the frame of Jesse's photo against the inside o metal trash can. Nancy winces and then smiles at the sound of shattering glass. Atwood plucks the photo out of the frame and tears it so the rip can be heard over the phone.
... tell him I couldn't find it.
Mr. Brooks is still asleep. Emma, dressed for the day, arrives at his side of the bed. She rubs the back of Mr. Brooks' hand.
Earl... Earl... Mr. Brooks opens his eyes.
(sleepy, groggy) Huh?...
Roger is on the phone.

In his slippers and robe, Mr. Brooks is standing in the Doorway watching Jane who is leaning over the Counter wit open Newspaper next to a bowl of cereal. He has a chance to take a good long look before she feels presence and raises her head.
Oh, Hi, Daddy, I thought you'd already be gone.
Roger called. There was another murder last night near Stanford.
Oh...
Done the same way as the one they talked to you about. Right down to the hatchet being left at the scene. Jane can't quite conceal the tremor of surprise that ripp through her and Mr. Brooks sees it.
They think they have a serial killer. Obviously you were here last night, so you're in the clear.
That's good news, isn't it? I mean even if you're innocent it's good news to know you're not a suspect.
Oh, yeah. How's the morning sickness? Do you want to ride in with me today?
I feel fine, but I don't know how long that will last. Mr. Brooks nods, turns to leave, then turns back.
Do you love me, Jane?
Of course I love you, daddy, you're my father.
Have you decided whether or not to keep the baby?
Not yet.
(nods) Okay.

head_text.subj: EXT. MR. SMITH'S CAR N AFTERNOON

text: Looking off the grill as it overtakes another car in the Fastlane. Eminem is on the stereo. The car ahead moves out of the w

head_text.subj: INT. MR. SMITH'S CAR N AFTERNOON

text: Mr. Smith is rapping along to "Cleanin' Out My Closet". H knows all the words.
With Eminem fading, we fall behind Mr. Smith. One car, tw cars. The third car is Detective Atwood's car.

head_text.subj: INT. DETECTIVE ATWOOD'S CAR N AFTERNOON

text: Atwood is driving. Snyder is in the passenger seat.
What are we doing?
'Are we there yet?' , are we there yet?' , you sound like a child. We're playing a hunch.
We've been following this guy all day, he's boring, and everything we run on him comes up clean.
If it didn't, it wouldn't be called a hunch.
Meeks' finger-prints were all over the chiropractor, the note, refrigerator, he's the guy we should be looking for.

Look where? Please tell me. Everyone knows who Meeks is and is looking for him. The chiropractor was the last link to his old life that I know of. The only way we'll find him, now, is if someone turns him in or we trip over him at a bus stop. On the other hand, Detective Snyder, no one knows who the Thumbprint Killer is or where he is. However, I have a fucking hunch this guy Baffert does. I have two days to play that hunch. If you feel like you're wasting your time with me, I'd be happy to do it alone. He looks at her and shakes his head.
I had a fight with my wife this morning; what's your problem?
My husband wants five million dollars.
Mr. Smith's car enters the Parking Lot of a Rib Joint. Atwood's car stops across the street.
Atwood and Snyder watch Mr. Smith enter the Restaurant. T wait in silence. A muted 'tone' announces the arrival of Email on their computer. Snyder reads and frowns.
Bad news?
Lister is pulling you off this case.
Why?!
Maybe they caught him. She twists the screen around so she can read the message.
No. She would have said that. Snyder points across the street at Mr. Smith coming out o the Restaurant carrying a Take-Out bag.
You want to keep following him? Atwood hesitates.
Lister only said you were off the case, not me.
(smiles) Good thinking, Tonto. She starts the car. There's the muted 'tone' again. Atwoo looks at the computer screen.
Shit! She just 86'ed you too.
Trailed by Snyder, Detective Atwood arrives at Captain Lister's SECRETARY.
Is she in?
She's with someone.
Good.
Atwood blows past the Secretary and opens the door to Lister's office.

head_text.subj: INT. CAPTAIN LISTER'S OFFICE N AFTERNOON

text: There are two MEN in suits on the other side of the desk the Captain. Atwood ignores them and focuses on Lister.
You promised if I settled my divorce I had three days on the Thumbprint Killer. I have the rest of today and tomorrow left.
Detective Atwood, meet FBI Agents Longnecker and Campbell, they're taking over your investigation.
You promised you would keep them out of it for three days.
They won't allow me to keep that promise. Atwood glares at her then at the FBI Men.
This is my case, what you're doing is fucked. But since I can't stop you, and she won't, here's a tip. James Baffert, you should stake him out, he knows something.
We have some other ideas we are looking into.
Then what's the problem? You do that and I'll tail Baffert.
Thank you for all your good work, Detective. This is our case now. Atwood looks from one Man to the Other.
Good luck. (to Captain Lister) Later I suppose you'll fill me in on what I'm supposed to be doing around here. I'm confused. She leaves. Snyder closes the door behind her.
It's deserted with only a small spill of light coming fro Mr. Brooks' Office.
Mr. Brooks is at his desk. The lamp at his elbow throws a yellow cone across his fac His head is in his hands, he's been crying. Marshall steps out of the shadows behind him.
It's time to go.
Yeah. He reaches into a bottom drawer and as he takes out an envelope, Marshall reads the tear-stained hand written le resting on the blotter.

Dear Emma and Jane, my loves, I have a terminal illness and instead of subjecting you to my deterioration, I have decided to disappear. Don't try to find me, I don't want to be found. Please believe that the time I spent with you brought me the greatest joy of my life. Love. Dad. Mr. Brooks picks up the letter and folds it.
So you're going to go through with it. Mr. Brooks stuffs the letter in the envelope, seals it an picks up a pen.
It's all planned to work out, Marshall. On the envelope he writes: For EMMA and JANE.

On the sidewalk Mr. Smith is walking toward the on-coming traffic. The headlights make it difficult to tell one car from the other until they pass. That doesn't keep him fro looking for Mr. Brooks. The houses stop and he's passing a pocket park. In a dark space between the street lamps, a hand falls on Mr. Smith shoulder. He jumps and a scream squeaks out of his throat It's Mr. Brooks, in his Pottery-Throwing clothes.
(smiles) Are you ready to rock and roll, Mr. Smith? Mr. Smith swallows hard and nods. Mr. Brooks propels him the park.

head_text.subj: INT. MR. BROOKS' CAR N NIGHT

text: Mr. Brooks is driving. Mr. Smith is in the passenger seat Both are lost in a wary silence. Abruptly from the back s
I smell gun oil, a gun oil that's different than yours.
He brought his gun. After he gets what he wants he plans to kill me.
Ah... now I get it. You were counting on that, weren't you?
It has a certain logic.
But if your plan is to have him kill you, why do you have to kill someone else first?
He'll need to see that to get up the courage to kill me. Marshall roars with laughter.

Not even you believe that, Earl. It makes it more exciting, doesn't it, to think he's going to kill you after you kill someone else. You're getting your rocks off big time, that's why you're doing it.
Not true... and if it were, so what? (to Mr. Smith) You're goddamn great, you know. To have the balls to do this.
I'm pretty nervous but that's normal right?
Perfectly normal.

head_text.subj: INT. DETECTIVE ATWOOD'S CONDOMINIUM N NIGHT

text: Atwood is propped up in bed reading a Magazine. Her hair pulled back and her face glistens with Cold Cream. The phone rings. Should she answer it? It rings again, th again. Reluctantly she grabs the receiver.

Hello... Oh, yes, yes. (she sits up) Put him through... Hi, this is Detective Atwood speaking, thanks for calling...Yes, your roommate said you were in Tokyo... Anything, if you saw anything at all it might be helpful.

head_text.subj: INT. FOUR STORY APARTMENT BUILDING N NIGHT

text: A MAN in a Flight Attendant's uniform is standing at the window of the Apartment he shares with the Stewardess.
A cordless phone to his ear, he is looking down at the Ho where the dance Couple was murdered.

The weird thing is that they closed their curtains, at first they were open like they always were and they were making love, which they always did, and then when I looked again the curtains were closed, and there were what looked like camera flashes coming from behind the curtains. INTERCUT with Detective Atwood.
Camera flashes?
That's what it looked like.
(almost to herself) That's why he poses them.
I'm sorry?
Nothing.
I wish I could be more helpful, I didn't see the killer or anything like that, but since it was weird I thought I should call.
You've been very helpful. This answers a lot of questions for me. Thank you very much, Mr. Struber. She's about to hang up when Struber speaks again.
The guy you should talk to is the guy on the floor below us...
FLIGHT ATTENDANT (CONT'D)
eh, I can't remember his name, but he told me once that he'd taken some great pictures of that Couple making love, he's the one you should speak to. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Would that be, Mr. Baffert? FLIGHT ATTENDANT
Yeah, I think Jim or James... DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Thank you very much. Atwood disconnects then quickly dials. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Snyder, meet me at Baffert's apartment with a Search Warrant... Listen to me, this is what you tell the judge.
Coming up the back STAIRS we arrive at a LANDING and make right. In front of us is Mr. Smith watching Mr. Brooks pi the deadbolt in the Service door.

Mr. Brooks straightens up, twists the handle and pushes t door inward. It's caught by a chain. He takes the bent ru tipped forceps from one pocket, from another he hands Mr. Smith a pair of latex gloves. MR. BROOKS
Put these on.

In the middle of the large darkened KITCHEN, Mr. Brooks pauses to listen to the sounds of the Apartment. The gun with the silencer is already in his right hand. B are encased in a Ziplock bag. Beside him, Mr. Smith is wide eyed with fear and anticipation. His teeth are even chattering. MR. BROOKS
Try a couple deep breaths through your nose.
I have to take a crap so bad.

This won't take long. Mr. Brooks and Mr. Smith come out of the Kitchen. The LIV ROOM is quite well appointed. There's a fire going in the Fireplace. The sound of a T.V. is coming from a ROOM off a HALL up ahead. That is where Mr. Brooks and Mr. Smith are headed. They're more than half way across the LIVING ROOM when DI DONG!, the doorbell rings. Mr. Smith gasps and looks beseechingly at Mr. Brooks. Wit an ounce of hurry, Mr. Brooks maneuvers him back into the shadows of the KITCHEN. The doorbell rings again. A wet spot appears in Mr. Smith's crotch and runs down hi pant leg. Pee drips onto the linoleum. A Man comes out of the Hallway. The Living Room light goe on. The Man is Jesse, Detective Atwood's estranged husband. He opens the Front Door. The Woman who comes in is Sheila, his divorce lawyer. They kiss, tongues. His hands brush over her breasts. He begins to unbutton her blouse. The kiss breaks. As he continues unbuttoning.
I called your wife's lawyer. They're thinking about the five million dollars. Jesse opens the blouse and looks at the breasts under the bra.
Realistically how much do you think we can get? Sheila gives him a quick kiss and moves on into the LIVIN ROOM where she drops her briefcase on the couch.
SHEILA

If we go to court, best case, two, if she wants to settle, best case, three, but I would be happy with two seven. Backlit by the Fireplace, Jesse kisses her again. From the KITCHEN, Mr. Brooks and Mr. Smith watch Jesse un Sheila's slacks and dropping to his knees peel them off h legs. She steps out of them. He kisses the inside of her thighs her crotch, then standing up: JESSE
I'll be right back. On his way out of the LIVING ROOM: JESSE
I think we should hold firm for three. He shuts off the light. In the glow of the Fireplace, She removes her jacket. SHEILA

Let's not be piggish, two five, two seven, would be a good deal. The T.V. goes silent. Jesse returns with a partially full glass of Champagne. He hands Sheila a glass from a side table, takes a bottle of an ice bucket and as he fills her glass: SHEILA
(teasing) You've already had half a bottle. JESSE
You're late; if we want it, there's more. They clink glasses. SHEILA
To us. JESSE
To three million dollars.
SHEILA
(after a sip) We have to do this fast because remember, Marie is meeting us here. JESSE
We could ask her to join us.
Not funny. JESSE

(undoing the front of her bra) I wasn't trying to be. She bops him playfully. He bends and slips a nipple into mouth. Sheila bites her lip and moans. In the KITCHEN, Mr. Smith shifts around for a better view The floor under him CRREEEKKS! In the LIVING ROOM, both Sheila and Jesse react to the so SHEILA
Are we alone?
Yeah. Mr. Brooks seems to appear magically out of the darkened Kitchen with his gun raised. He's followed by Mr. Smith. Sheila opens her mouth to scream. MR. BROOKS
Don't do that.

head_text.subj: INT. MR. SMITH'S APARTMENT BUILDING N NIGHT

text: Detective Atwood hurries down the HALL and out of breath, stops in front of Mr. Smith's door. She raps sharply. Wai bare three seconds and raps again. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Mr. Baffert?... Mr. Baffert? The door of the Apartment behind her opens and an OLDER W sticks her head out.
He's gone.
Atwood shows her badge.
Do you have any idea when he'll be back?
He skipped out. I heard him leave this evening and a few minutes later there were Movers here. Musta been behind on the rent. He didn't even say good-bye.

Thank you. As the Old Lady watches, Atwood tries the knob. It's unlocked. She pushes the door open. The HALLWAY and LIVING ROOM she can see are completely em Furniture, T.V., camera equipment, art, gone.
I told you.

head_text.subj: INT. MR. SMITH'S APARTMENT N NIGHT

text: On her way in, Atwood draws her gun. Keeping close to the walls she audits the KITCHEN. All th Cabinet doors are open. Dishes, pots and pans, cutlery, g She moves on to the BATHROOM. Soap, shampoo, toilet paper toothpaste, toothbrushes, towels, washcloths, the content the Medicine Cabinet, gone. She moves on to the BEDROOM. Bed, night table, lamps, T.V computer, gone. Clothes closets, empty of everything. She looks around. Mr. Smith's entire Apartment has been stripped absolutely clean, except... ... there's a crumpled piece of paper in the far corner o the Bedroom. Atwood goes over and gets down on one knee. With her fing pulling at the corners she is able to straighten the pape enough to make out that it's a work order from a Moving company.
Reading it with the paper pinched between thumb and forefinger of her left hand, Atwood rises. There's the silhouette of a Man in the doorway behind her.
Obviously Baffert's gone... Atwood whirls, gun up. She sees that it's Snyder.
(overlapping) Goddamit, Snyder. Knock.
I wasn't able to get the search warrant.
We may have gotten lucky. (holding up the paper) This is the Moving Company's work order and... (points)) ... it looks like this is the address where they're taking Baffert's stuff.
Where were you when you called me?
At home in bed.
Can you prove that?
I was home in bed, why should I have to prove that?
Your husband Jesse and his lawyer were killed tonight... Atwood slowly lowers her head and fixes her eyes on the f in stunned silence.
It looks like the Thumbprint Killer, I've been ordered to bring you in for questioning.
DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Why, I didn't want Jesse dead, I loved him, I hated what he was doing to me... SNYDER
It's on record you said you'd like him dead and who better to fake a Thumbprint killing than you. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
You can't actually believe I would do that. SNYDER
If our jobs have taught us anything, Tracy, is that people do strange things. They just want to ask you some questions. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I will be happy to answer any questions after we check out this address. Atwood goes to leave the room. Snyder blocks her way. SNYDER
I have to take you in, Tracy. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(waves the paper) This is the answer to the Thumbprint Killer, Snyder, and this is where I'm going and you're not going to stop me. SNYDER
Don't make me cuff you, Tracy, because I will if I have to. Atwood smiles winningly. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I believe you would. SNYDER
(smiles back) You can count on it.
Snyder never sees it coming. WHACK! Atwood's right cross nails him exactly where the jaw meets the neck and down h goes on his ass. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(standing over him) It would be nice if you could come with me, but if you do and it goes bad, they'll burn your ass. So this never happened.
Mr. Brooks' car speeds under an overpass.

head_text.subj: INT. MR. BROOKS' CAR N NIGHT

text: MR. SMITH
That was great! It was fantastic! It was everything I hoped it would be. Thank you. MR. BROOKS
You're welcome. In the back seat: MARSHALL
Here comes the gun. Without taking his eyes off the road.
Yup. Mr. Smith slides a pistol from under his jacket and point at Mr. Brooks. MR. BROOKS
(feigns surprise) What are you doing?! MR. SMITH
You're smart enough to figure that out, Mr. Brooks. MR. BROOKS
Well we're going sixty five miles an hour, Mr. Smith, if you shoot me now, there's a good chance we'll both die.
Not now. Take the next off ramp.
That wouldn't be very smart of me would it? He accelerates around a truck into the Fastlane. Mr. Smit can see the Exit coming up, it's quickly left behind.

(matter of fact) Think about this. You pissed yourself back there, you left your DNA at the scene of a double homicide, and there's nothing to indicate that I was ever there. If the Cops do an analysis of that urine, and they will, you're the Thumbprint Killer.
(smug) No. I still have pictures of you doing the first murder. Mr. Brooks smiles a knowing smile. Beyond him on the othe side of the Divider, cars are zipping by in the opposite direction.
Yes. But what were you doing at the second murder? Mr. Smith doesn't have an answer for that.

Let me help you with a thought. You say I forced you to come along and if I'm not here or more specifically my body is not here to say different, you might have a chance to beat the rap. Now you're probably asking yourself why I would help you. I'm tired, Mr. Smith, I'm tired of killing. But I'm an addict, I can't quit. I've tried. I can't do it on my own. So I'll let you kill me but I want you to do it smart, in a way that I disappear and my family never knows what I was.
MR. SMITH
How do I do that? MR. BROOKS

There's a cemetery I know about. We find an open grave, you shoot me, I fall in the grave, you shovel in just enough earth to cover me, tomorrow a casket is lowered onto me and I've disappeared. It's a good plan. What do you say?... MR. SMITH
Why should I trust you? MR. BROOKS
You don't have to trust me. You're the man holding the gun, you saw me put mine in the trunk. MR. SMITH
I don't know. You really want me to kill you? MR. BROOKS
Yes. MR. SMITH
Okay... But any sudden moves and you're dead on the spot and I'll make sure your family knows what you are. MR. BROOKS
I understand.

head_text.subj: EXT. OLD DECO BUILDING N NIGHT

text: Come off the banner hanging across the front - ROOMS FOR RENT, to find Atwood walking away from her car. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
(to herself, regarding the Building) You've come down in the world, Mr. Baffert.
High ceilings, once grand, now blue neon and a cage aroun the Front Desk to protect the Night Clerk who is nowhere sight. Somewhere a radio is playing salsa music loud.
Atwood crosses to the elevator. She pushes the call butto With an arthritic rattle the door opens.
Atwood selects the 5th Floor. Creek!, Clatter!, Clank!, t door closes and after a stuttering liftoff the car begins ascent. The overhead light flickers on and off. Atwood lo up at it.

Mr. Brooks leads Mr. Smith across a street to a pedestria gate set in a high wall. Through the bars of the gate we can see a Cemetery bathed moonlight. Mr. Brooks reaches into his pocket. Mr. Smith tightens hi grip on the gun.
Uh uh, take your hand out real slow. Mr. Brooks does as he's told. A key dangles from his fing
It's locked. You don't want to climb over, do you?
What are you doing with a key to a cemetery?
I own it.
Why do you own a cemetery? Mr. Brooks unlocks the gate and preceding Mr. Smith, goes inside.
You always want to invest in things people can't do without. Water and cemeteries are pretty safe. He locks the gate and handing the key to Mr. Smith:
You'll need this to get out. Now there should be an open grave around here somewhere. Let's see if we can find it. He produces a small flashlight from his pocket and off th go.

head_text.subj: INT. OLD DECO BUILDING N NIGHT

text: Repeating their arthritic performance the elevator doors open. Atwood steps out into a wide sporadically lit HALLW Peering at the numbers Atwood goes to her Left. In the middle of the Hall behind her a Couple exits a Roo and drifts to the other side of the Hall on their way to elevator. Atwood re-checks the number on the Moving Company's Work Order - 517, she's going the wrong way. She turns around. Now Atwood and the Couple are walking toward each other o opposite sides of the Hall. Atwood steps into an area of light. The reflection off her face catches the attention of the who is wearing a wide brimmed hat. He lifts his head. It's Thorton Meeks. The Woman with him was the Driver of Van. She's wearing a watchcap. Meeks gently takes his Companion's arm. They stop. Her ey go to where he's looking and then back to his. At some unspoken signal they both draw their guns. Intent on finding 517 and Baffert, the Couple hasn't registered on Atwood's radar. BANG! TWOCK! A chunk of plaster blows off the wall next t her head. Startled, Atwood winces away. BANG! The Woman fires. The slug explodes the plaster on the other side of Atwood's head. Now Atwood is turning toward them, gun in hand. Meeks fires. The bullet passes through Atwood's jacket.

Instinctively Atwood assumes a classic duelist's pose offering the smallest target possible. Calmly she squeeze off her first shot. The plaster explodes from the wall above Meeks' head. The Woman fires. A hole appears in Atwood's sleeve. Atwood pulls the trigg again. SMACK! The Woman screams and falls back into Meeks, a bul in her hip. Atwood's third shot takes the hat off Meeks h She now realizes who her attackers are.

Meeks?!! Dragging the Woman in the direction of the stairs, BANG! Meeks fires. Maybe it's his broken trigger finger that affects his aim. The shots miss. BANG! BANG! The Woman fi Atwood's next two shots miss. Meeks and the Woman arrive at the stairs and before round the corner, BANG! BANG! BANG!, fire at Atwood who is now moving deliberately at them. Atwood doesn't try and dodge the bullets or flinch away f them and her shots are unhurried. The next one catches the Woman in the side. The one after that nails Meeks in the left shoulder. He's spun into the Woman.
Leaning on each other Meeks and the Woman lurch down the marble steps.

Atwood reaches the stairs and cheats a look around the corner. BANG! BANG! BANG! From the landing below, Meeks a the Woman fire. Atwood steps out from behind the wall and shoulders squar shoots. Another sidestep. This shot shatters Meeks' knee. bellows in pain.
Moving to the side again, Atwood shoots. But Meeks' knee collapsed and he and the Woman are already tumbling down next set of steps. Atwood waits. There's silence, then th murmur of voices.
(calls out) Atwood?
Yeah.
Come on down, there's something I want to show you.

Gun at the ready, Atwood edges her way downward. At about tenth step she is able to lean over and look through the banisters. Meeks and the Woman are propping themselves up against th wall on the LANDING below. Both of them still have their guns. The moment Meeks' eyes meet Atwood's, he puts his gun to Woman heads. BANG! Atwood sucks in her breath. Meeks puts the gun to his temple. BANG! Atwood clasps a hand to her mouth and exhales in ragged gulps.
The finger of light from Mr. Brooks' handtorch discovers freshly dug GRAVE.
There we are. Now if I stand here... He positions himself at one end of the Grave.
... and you stand there, not too far away and you shoot me, I should fall straight back into the hole.
You don't think I have the guts to do this do you?
I'm hoping you do. Mr. Brooks shuts off his light and straightens up.
Okay, let's get this over with. Mr. Smith raises his gun and points it at Mr. Brooks's he He hesitates.
I'll close my eyes. He does. Mr. Smith pulls the trigger. Click! Mr. Smith looks in horror at the malfunctioning gun. Mr. Brooks opens his eyes. Mr. Smith aims the gun again. Click!... Click!
I'm sorry. As he talks he counters around until Mr. Smith is the one with his back to the open Grave.

I really did want you to kill me. But in case at the last minute I changed my mind, I returned to your apartment and bent the firing pin on your gun. He wrenches the shovel out of a mound of waiting earth. M Smith tries to fire the gun at Mr. Brooks again.
In fact I even brought another gun for you so you could finish me if I had decided to go through with it. He opens his jacket and shows Mr. Smith the gun.
MR. BROOKS
Unfortunately for you, my daughter is pregnant and just before you pulled the trigger, I realized how much I want to see the end to that story. MR. SMITH
(dry mouth) If you do anything to me, if you touch one hair on my head, the Police will find the pictures of you killing that Couple. MR. BROOKS

The contents of your safety deposit box, Mr. Smith, have vanished. Without warning, Mr. Brooks swings the shovel. The force the blow breaks Mr. Smith's left arm. He howls. The next blow comes almost immediately. It smashes into t left side of Mr. Smith's head. The screams stop and a misfiring set of neurons causes Mr Smith to stand up straight and wobbling, look directly at Brooks. The blood streaming down his face is black in the moonlig Mr. Brooks takes a step to the side, cocks his wrists and swings again. His full weight is behind this one. The blade of the shovel strikes Mr. Smith in the throat v nearly taking off his head. The flesh that was once Mr. S falls to the ground. MR. BROOKS
(looking down at the corpse) Before I was the Thumbprint Killer, Mr. Smith, I killed a lot of people in a lot of different ways.
Looking up. Mr. Smith's body is rolled over the edge. It falls on top of us.
Mr. Brooks takes a shovel of dirt from the pile and whist 'By The Light Of The Silvery Moon', begins the task of covering Mr. Smith.

A Newspaper is lying unfolded on the Counter next to the remnants of a breakfast. The headline reads - NATIONWIDE MANHUNT FOR THUMBPRINT KI - Under that headline is a large picture of Mr. Smith aka Baffert. In the lower right corner is another headline to a story Murder Suicide For The Hangman -. The reader of the paper is Mr. Brooks. On a stool next to him, Marshall is also reading. MARSHALL
It says here the Thumbprint Killer is a monster... annoys you a little bit that you can't take credit, doesn't it? MR. BROOKS
Anyone who is good at what they do, wants recognition. But since I'm not going to do it anymore, I'll let Mr. Smith take the credit. MARSHALL
Don't kid yourself, Earl, you're going to kill again. MR. BROOKS

No, I'm not. I'll continue the AA meetings and I'll control it. On the other stool next to Mr. Brooks is a WOMAN. Her lar purse hangs open from the back of the stool; the cel phon clearly visible inside. Mr. Brooks looks at the phone. MR. BROOKS
But there is an answer I would like to have.
Detective Atwood is seated in her CUBICLE reading the sam front page Mr. Brooks was reading. A FELLOW OFFICER stops the door. OFFICER
Good work, Atwood. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Thanks, Tom. He moves on. From off screen: ANOTHER OFFICER
You should ask the FBI to kiss your ass and buy you a Cadillac. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I like my ass too much for that. Snyder comes in and holds up the Work Order from the Movi Company. SNYDER
This is bogus. The company doesn't exist in the city, the state, the United States or Canada. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
So the whole point of this piece of paper was to give me Meeks. SNYDER
That's what it looks like. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
Why? Who moved him, where did they move him to, and why did he give me Meeks? SNYDER
That's what we get paid to find out. Atwood picks up the Newspaper. DETECTIVE ATWOOD
I'm going to go to the bathroom and think about this. She stands. The phone rings. She answers it.
Detective Atwood...

head_text.subj: EXT. ROOFTOP PARKING LOT N MORNING

text: Looking out at the city, Mr. Brooks speaks into the cel p he stole from the Woman.
Why are you a cop? INTERCUT with Atwood.
Who is this?
You're rich, you have a good education, you could have gone into your father's business, instead you went outside all of that and became successful on your own. Why?
You want something from me if you don't tell me who you are I'm going to hang up.
Did you think your husband's killing was random and I certainly didn't have to give you Meeks.
Mr. Baffert?! Snyder perks up. She points for him to get on the other l
What's the answer?
You don't sound like you.
I have a little cold. Are you going to give me the answer?
Where are you?
I'll tell you if you can give me the true answer to my question. Detective Atwood weighs her options and decides to go for
My father was very disappointed I was born a girl and he let me know that. I've spent my whole life trying to prove him wrong.
Thank you.
Wait. You promised to tell me where you are.
Me? I'm on top of a building. Atwood and Snyder hear the click as Mr. Brooks hangs up.
Why would he be interested in that? At the Parking structure, Mr. Brooks holds the phone over edge and drops it. We follow the phone down, down, down, until it hits the pavement and disintegrates.
Everything is as it was.
It's dark. In his robe and pajamas, Mr. Brooks is standin front of the open refrigerator gazing blankly at the cont with a glass of milk in one hand. There's nothing he want here. He closes the door.
Carrying the glass of milk, Mr. Brooks passes Jane's ROOM The door is ajar. He stops, backs up and looks. His Daughter's asleep.

Mr. Brooks walks to the bed and leans over to give her a on the cheek. His lips have just brushed her flesh when she twists violently under him and stabs upward with a pair of sciss The blades are driven deep into his throat. Mr. Brooks je back, the milk flies out of his hand. MR. BROOKS
Agghhh!!! Agghhh!!! He grabs at the handle of the scissors, but his blood mak them too slippery. He can't pull them out. EMMA (V.O.)
Honey, Earl, Earl...
Mr. Brooks is tossing in his sleep next to Emma. She has hold of his arm. EMMA
Wake up, wake up... On the pillow Mr. Brooks' eyes fly open. EMMA
You were having a nightmare. MR. BROOKS
(breathing hard) Oh... I woke you up.
It's okay. She kisses him on the forehead. EMMA (CONT'D)

I'm here, go back to sleep, I'm here. Taking his hand, she lies back down. After a moment Mr. Brooks turns over on his side and looks directly at us. H lips begin to move but we can't hear what he's saying, so move in on his face. It's not until it fills our view tha can hear the words.
... that I may be reasonably happy in this life, And supremely happy with Him forever in the next. Amen. .... God grant me the Serenity to accept...
